entry.title: How to Build Stock Validation Skills in Joule Studio
entry.content:
Build Maintenance Validation Skills Using Joule Studio  in SAP Build (Part 1)

Intro: Empowering Maintenance Operations with Joule Skills

Joule Studio enables business users and developers to build Joule Skills that automate backend tasks and simplify decision-making. In this hands-on guide — the first of a two-part series —We’ll walk through creating a set of Joule Skills that help retrieve maintenance orders, fetch material and component details, and check stock availability, forming the foundation for intelligent decision-making, using a CAP-based service on SAP BTP.

We’ll focus specifically on how to design, build, and test Joule Skills inside Joule Studio. The backend logic used to check maintenance order status and stock availability is already deployed as a reusable service on SAP BTP and exposed through a destination.  

Use Case: Intelligent Maintenance Stock Validation 

Maintenance planners often face delays when required components for maintenance orders are unavailable. The validation process today is manual and error prone. 

With Joule Studio, we can automate this. Our Joule Skills we’ll build will: 

  • Retrieve pending maintenance orders 
  • Identify components required 
  • Check material stock availability 
  • Return the result to the user or agent consuming the skill

 

Now that we've outlined the business challenge and solution approach, let's dive into the hands-on implementation. We'll build this step-by-step, starting with the foundational setup and progressing through skill creation.

Prerequisites

Before we begin building our maintenance validation skills, you'll need access to Joule Studio. If you don't have Joule Studio set up yet, please follow the comprehensive setup guide available at: How to Get Started with Joule Studio

This guide will walk you through:

  • Accessing Joule Studio in your SAP BTP environment
  • Setting up the necessary entitlements and subscriptions
  • Configuring your development environment
  • Understanding the basic Joule Studio interface

Our Development Approach:

  1. First, we'll establish the connection to our backend service.
  2. Then, we'll create individual skills for each business function.
  3. Finally, we'll test and deploy our skills for use.

Step 1: Configure the Destination in SAP Build Lobby 

To connect Joule Studio to the backend service, you’ll first configure a destination directly in the SAP Build Control Tower. 

This destination will point to an already deployed CAP service that exposes the necessary maintenance order and stock validation logic. 

Create a New Destination 

  1. Navigate to the SAP Build Lobby .
  2. Go to Control Tower > Destinations.
  3. Click “Open in BTP Cockpit”.
  4. In the BTP Cockpit, Navigate to:
    • Connectivity > Destinations

 

5. Click Create Destination and fill in the following configuration: 

  • Name: sample-maintenance-service 
  • Type: HTTP 
  • Description: Maintenance Order Service
  • URL: https://sample-maintenance-srv-i760021.cfapps.eu12.hana.ondemand.com/odata/v4/maintenance-order 
  • Proxy Type: Internet 
  • Authentication: BasicAuthentication 
  • User: TECHNICAL_USER 
  • Password: TECHNICAL_PASS

 

 

 

6.  Click Check Connection to verify the destination. You should see a green checkmark if the connection is successful.

Step 2: Create an Environment in SAP Build 

Before adding destinations or creating skills in Joule Studio, you need to create an environment in SAP Build. This environment acts as the runtime space where your agents and skills will be deployed and executed. 

To create an environment: 

  1. Open the SAP Build Lobby 
  2. Navigate to Control Tower > Environments 
  3. Click Create Environment 
  4. Enter a name for your environment, e.g., Joule studio demo 
  5. (Optional) Add a description if needed 
  6. Click Create 

Later, you’ll associate your destination and actions with this environment to make them usable in your skills and agents 

Step 3: Add the Destination to SAP Build  

Now that your destination is created in BTP, as we did in Step 1, we need to make it available inside SAP Build to use it in Joule Studio. 

  1. Open SAP Build Lobby 
  2. Navigate to Control Tower > Destinations 
  3. Click Add 
  4. In the wizard: Select your destination (e.g. sample-maintenance-service) 
  5. Click Next 
  6. Associate an Environment 
    1. Select the environment you created in Step 2(e.g., Joule_studio_demo) 
    2. You can choose to make the destination available in all environments or only the specific environment which you created in step 2 .
  7. Click Add Destination 

Once added, this destination will now be available to associate with environments and to use in Joule skills. 

Step 4: Add an Action in SAP Build (Expose Your API) 

Now that your destination is available and associated with an environment, the next step is to create an Action that defines how your backend API should be called by Joule skills. 

Actions are the bridge between destinations (backend APIs) and Joule Skills. 

You can upload an open API specification or build an action from scratch using the destination you added. 

Option 1: Upload OpenAPI Spec from Your Project 

  1. Go to Control Tower > Actions 
  2. Click Create > Upload API Specification 
  3. Note:The API spec is provided as a .txt file containing JSON content in the attachment.
    Before uploading, rename the file to have a .json extension  so Joule Studio correctly detects the format.
  4. Upload your openapi.json file. 
  5. Click Next to continue 
  6. You’ll now be prompted to Create an Action Project. 
  7. Fill in Project Name and Description according to your use case.
    • For example, you can name the project Maintenance Fulfillment Agent API , since these APIs will later be used by a Joule Agent (covered in Part 2 of this series). 
  8. After creating the action project, you will see a list of all endpoints from your uploaded specification (you can select maximum up to 20) 
    • Select all the 5 endpoints needed for your use case. 
    • Click Add to include them in the project. 

8. Once the action is created, go to the Test tab and select the destination you created. Since the maintenance order API lists all orders, no input is required by default. If you'd like to filter by status (e.g., pending, open), you can add that later as an input parameter. Click Test to verify that the API returns a valid response. 

 

9. You should see 200: OK response from the API. 

Once tested, you can release the project to create a version of it. 

 

 10.Once released, click Publish to make the version available for Joule Skill creation 

Note: Releasing and publishing the action is required. Unpublished actions won’t appear when building a Joule Skill. 

Option 2: Alternatively: Build the Action from Scratch 

  1. Go to Control Tower > Actions 
  2. Click Create > Build from Scratch 
  3. Fill in the required fields: 
    • Operation: GET 
    • Name: Enter a name for your action (e.g., CheckMaintenanceStock) 
    • Description: Enter a brief description (e.g., Checks stock for components in a maintenance order) 
    • Endpoint: eg., /MaintenanceOrder) 
  4. Define any request parameters and expected response fields. 
  5. Click Release and Publish the action just like in the previous method for the actions to be available. 

For our use case, we will be using Option 1. 

Step 5: Create a Project and Joule Skills 

Now that the destination is configured, the environment is created, and your action has been added and published, you’re ready to build a custom Joule Skill that calls the required API from your service. 

These skills will be reusable and can later be connected to an intelligent agent in Part 2 of this series.

Create a New Skill Project 

  1. Open Joule Studio in SAP Build. 
  2. Click on create > Create Skill  
  3. Enter 
    • Project Name: eg., Intelligent Maintenance Order Stock Validation Agent   
    • Description: e.g., Skills to validate whether maintenance orders can be fulfilled based on stock availability
  4. Note: While we’re only creating Joule Skills in this post, we’ll use the same project to add and configure the Joule Agent in Part 2 of this series.
  5. Click Review > Create 

Once the project is created, you’ll be taken to the Overview tab, where you’ll see the project name and description. 

 

 

The project will be created after you click “Create”.  

Add a New Joule Skill 

  1. In the project, click Create 
  2. From the dropdown, select Joule Skill.
  3. Fill in: 
    • Name: e.g., Check Maintenance Order Details 
    • Identifier: e.g., checkMaintenanceOrderDetails
    • Description: e.g.,check about particular maintenance order using id number 
    • Click Create 

 

 

 

Add the Parameters to the Skill 

  1. Open the skill by clicking its name or the arrow icon to the left .This is the panel where you need to add input, output parameters.  
  2. In the “General” tab, update the name/description of the Joule skill. 
  3. Keep the toggle “Allow skill to be started directly by a user” ON (so the skill can be started directly by the user, not just via an agent).

     

  4. Go to the Parameters tab. Click Configure to add input and output parameters. 
  5. Inputs allow Joule to collect user input in the conversation interface. 
  6. Outputs define what information will be shown to the user after the skill executes. Add the input parameter:

     

➕Add Input 

  1. Add the following Input: 
    • Name: Maintenance id number
    • Description: maintenance ID number
    • Required: Checked 
    • Click Apply to save the input. 

 

➕Add Output 

  1. Add the following Output: 
    • Name:ID Details
      • Type:String
      • List: UnChecked 
      • Required: Checked 
      • Description: maintenance order number
    • Name:count
      • Type:String
      • List: UnChecked 
      • Required: Checked 
      • Description: count of maintenance order.
    • Name:Operations
      • Type:Any
      • List: Checked 
      • Required: Checked 
      • Description: list of maintenance operations
    • Name: scheduledStartDate
      • Type:DateTime
      • List: UnChecked 
      • Required: Checked 
      • Description: start date
    • Name: scheduledEndDate
      • Type:DateTime
      • List: UnChecked 
      • Required: Checked 
      • Description: end date
  2. Click Apply to save the output. 
  3. Output types can vary — choose the appropriate type based on the structure of your API response. 
  4. You’ve now configured both input and output parameters for your Joule skill. 

 

Add an Action Step to the Skill 

  1. Click the ➕Plus icon to add a step
    1.  
  2. Select Call Action 
  3. In the Action search: 
    • Either browse all actions 
    • Or use the search bar to quickly find your previously published action (e.g., GetMaintenanceOrderDetails) 
    • Click Add 

 

 

 

 

Configure the Action Step 

  1. After adding the action, you’ll see General, Input, and Output tabs. 
  2. In the General tab: 
    • Set Step Name: Get maintenance orders 
    • For Destination Variable, create or select one (e.g., Fulfillment_agent) 
    • Click Create to add the destination, then select it.

       

  3. Go to the Input tab and map the input (e.g., user query).

     

  4. In the Output tab, you can view the API’s response schema.

     

  5. Click End to configure the skill’s outputs and map the expected output value. 
  6. Click Save to finish the step configuration. 

 

 

Create Skills for Each API Endpoint 

We have already created a skill which uses GET/MaintenanceOrder('{ID}')

 

Tool Name 

Endpoint 

Description 

GetMaintenanceOrderDetails 

GET /MaintenanceOrder('{ID}') 

Get details of a specific maintenance order 

GetOrderOperations 

GET /MaintenanceOrder('{ID}')/operation 

List operations under a maintenance order 

GetOperationComponents 

GET /Operation('{ID}')/component 

List components for a specific operation 

GetMaterialDetails 

GET /Material('{ID}') 

Get material details 

GetMaterialStockLevels 

GET /Material('{ID}')/stockLevel 

Check stock availability for a material 

 

For each skill, remember to: 

  • Configure input and output parameters.
  • Set the correct destination variable.
  • Turn on “Allow skill to be started directly by a user” if creating Joule Skills.

Tip: Use the Action Definition to Configure Skill Parameters 

When configuring the Skill Input and Skill Output, you don’t need to guess what the API expects or returns. 

You can find this information directly from the Action definition you uploaded earlier: 

  1. Go to Control Tower > Actions.
  2. Open the Action project you created .
  3. Select the relevant endpoint.
  4. Navigate to the Input and Output tabs 

From there, you can: 

  • See which input parameters are required 
  • Understand the expected output structure and data types 

 

 

 

 

Example: For GET /Operation('{ID}')/component 

  • Input: ID of the operation (marked with a red asterisk = required) .
  • Output: 
    • value → A list of components (type: list) 
    • count → Number of items (type: number) 

Use this information to accurately define the parameters in your Joule Skill > Parameters tab. 

  

Step 6: Release and Deploy Joule Skills 

With your Joule Skills created and configured, the next step is to release and deploy them to your environment so they can be used in real scenarios.

  1. Click Release to version your Project.

 

 

       2. Go to Project > Versions 

       3. Click Deploy 

 

 

During deployment: 

  1. Select the Environment created in Step 2 (e.g., Joule Studio demo) 
  2. Select the Destination you added in Step 3 
    • You will only see destinations that are: 
      • Associated with this environment 
      • Or made available to All Environments 
  3. Click Deploy 
  4. After deployment, the agent status will appear as Active 

 

 

 

Test the Skills in Joule Studio

To interact with your the skills: 

  1. Go to Control Tower > Environments 
  2. Click your environment (e.g., joule studio demo) 
  3. Under your agent project, click More > Joule 
  4. Click Launch to open the Joule Chat window 

You can now start chatting with your agent using real-world prompts. 

 

For example: 


Debugging Agents Flow 

  • You can open the Debug Panel in the top right corner to see details of how Joule selects the skills based on the user input.  

Example Prompts to Test the Joule skills

  1. “Give me the open/pending 5 maintenance orders”

  2. “When is Maintenance Order with ID 1 supposed to be scheduled?”
  3. “What all material is required for maintenance order 12?”
  4. “How many stock is available for material id 25?”
  5. “Can you give me details about material for id 39?”
  6. “How many stock is available for material id 25 and in which warehouse can it be found?”
  7. “Give me operation details required for maintenance order 30?”
  8. “What is the status for operation with ID 30?”
  9. “What all components are required for operation 12?”
  10. “What are the materials used for component 25?” 
  11. How many units of material M-45678 are in stock?

Wrapping Up Part 1: Skills First, Intelligence Next

In this first part of our Joule Studio blog series, we focused on building the foundation: creating, configuring, and deploying individual Joule Skills that interact with maintenance orders and material data. These skills are now live, testable, and ready to be reused across various automation and intelligence layers.

Each skill is designed to handle a focused task — whether it’s fetching order details, retrieving stock levels, or listing required components. With these deployed, you're now ready to take the next leap: combining them into an intelligent agent.

In Part 2, we’ll build a Joule Agent that brings your deployed skills together into an intelligent assistant — one that can understand maintenance-related questions, check if orders can be fulfilled, identify what’s blocking them, and even suggest solutions such as replenishment needs or follow-up actions.


Part 2 will show you how to build an intelligent maintenance agent that brings your skills to life — stay tuned!

If you're interested in diving deeper into Joule Studio and expanding your knowledge beyond this use case, here are valuable resources to accelerate your learning:

Learning Resources

  • Learning Journey - Comprehensive guided learning path for Joule Studio
  • Documentation - Official technical documentation and reference guides
  • Discovery Center Mission - Hands-on missions to build practical skills
  • Joule Studio Tutorials - Step-by-step development tutorials
  • Architecture Overview - Technical architecture and integration patterns
  • Smart Advisory Companion – Inspiration Video - See Joule Studio in action with real-world scenarios

These resources will help you explore additional use cases, advanced features, and best practices for building intelligent automation solutions with Joule Studio.

entry.title: step by step guide for using Governance Rule to control transport in SAP Build
entry.content:
Now SAP Build allows users to create Governance Rules from templates, and use the predefined processes to control the creation and transport of their projects.

In this blog post we will look at how to implement it. We will start by setting up Cloud Transport Management Service (cTMS) to enable the transport between SAP Build Process Automation (SBPA) tenants, and then continue with adding governance rule in SAP Build to set an approval gateway before the content goes to Transport Management Service. 

 

The following articles are mainly referred to:

  • [SAP Help Portal] Configure Governance Rules https://help.sap.com/docs/build/sap-build-core/configure-governance-rules?locale=en-US
  • [SAP Help Portal] Documentation of the integration with SAP Cloud Transport Management: Transport a Project
  • [SAP Help Portal] SAP Content Agent Service https://help.sap.com/docs/content-agent-service/user-guide/create-target-node-destination
  • [SAP Blog] Transporting content in SAP BUILD Process Automation https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-members/transporting-content-in-sap-build-process-automation/bc-p/13556499
  • [SAP Blog] Configure Governance Rules in SAP Build https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-sap/configure-governance-rules-in-sap-build/ba-p/14133093
  • [SAP Developers YouTube channel video] Set Up Rules for Who Can Create and Transport SAP Build Projects https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=aLJTpAwYxyM&t=9s

Prerequisites:

  • You have a source SBPA tenant, and a target SBPA tenant (application subscription), and you have access to them and their Subaccounts.
  • You have subscription to cTMS tenant and you have access to it and its Subaccount.

Step 1: create service instances and their destinations

If you have not set up Transport for SBAP, you will need to start with creating several service instances and their destinations. If you are already able to transport contents from one SBPA tenant to another, then you can skip the first three steps and directly go to Step 4. 

This allow cTMS and SBPA to talk to each other via CAS. CAS is always free. 

The architecture will eventually look like: 

Step 1.1 create service instance and service key for cTMS

In the same Subaccount of cTMS subscription, create a service instance and service key, see Steps to use Transport Management using Programmatic Access (API Remote Call).

 

Step 1.2: create Content Agent Service (CAS) instances in source and target subaccounts

In each of the Subaccounts of source and target SBPA, a CAS's service instance need to be created. Choose Application plan for this service instance and choose Admin role in the creation wizard. A service key need to be created for the service instance. Note, you can also subscribe to the CAS multi-tenant application, and that is a different plan than the Application plan for service instance. Please do not mistake with the Standard service instance plan here, because the Standard service instance plan is used for assembling Integration Suite related artifacts into a mtar file.

 

 

See Create Instance and Create Service Key.

 

Step 1.3: create destinations for Content Agent Service (CAS) instances

And then, in the subaccount of cTMS, create two transport destinations pointing to the CAS service instances of source and target SAP BTP subaccounts. If you decide to have more than two nodes in your transport route, for instance you have dev, test and prod nodes, then you should create three destinations to point to all the three nodes.

 

Field

Sample Value

Explanation

Name

cas-trial

Enter a custom name for the destination. 

Type

HTTP

HTTP

Description

(optional)

You can provide a description for your reference. This field is optional.

URL

https://content-agent-assembly.cfapps.<region>.hana.ondemand.com

Copy and paste from the url in your CAS service key, not to mix with uaa→url.

Proxy Type

Internet

Internet

Authentication

OAuth2ClientCredentials

OAuth2ClientCredentials

Client ID

***

Copy and paste from the uaa →clientid from the service key details.

Client Secret

***

Copy and paste from the uaa →clientsecret from the service key details.

Use mTLS for Token Retrieval (Recommended)

(optional)

Select the checkbox, if you want to use mTLS (mutual TLS) for Oauth2ClientCredentials authentication. This is only applicable for proxy type Internet.

Token Service Key Store Location

(optional)

Upload a certificate using the Upload and Delete Certificateslink.

After uploading the keystore, select a name from the dropdown list.

Token Service Key Store Password

(optional)

Password for the keystore and the key pair contained in the keystore when using Oauth2ClientCredentials with mTLS.

Token Service URL Type

Dedicated

Dedicated

Token Service URL

https://<subdomain>.authentication.<region>.hana.ondemand.com/oauth/token

Copy and paste from the  uaa → url from the CAS service key, and then append the value oauth/token to the end.

For mTLS, use uaa → certurl, and then append the value oauth/token to the end.

Token Service User

 

No inputs required.

Token Service Password

 

No inputs required.

Use Basic credentials for Token Service

(do not choose)

Leave it blanked

Use default client trust store

Yes

Select the checkbox.

 

See Creating Destinations Using SAP Content Agent Service.

 

Step 2: create a route with the source and target nodes

Step 2.1: create route in cTMS

With the source and target CAS created, you can now go to cTMS, create a route, with source and target nodes using the destinations that you created for the source and targeted CAS. For details about how to create nodes and routes, you can use route wizard to create one route and two nodes in one minute, details please check: 

  • create transport node Create Transport Nodes. Create transport nodes as representations of the source and target end points of deployment processes in your landscape. Add configuration details as required.
  • create transport route Create Transport Routes. In SAP Cloud Transport Management, transport routes are used to connect transport nodes.

 

Please note that the content type for process automation in SBPA is MTA, as listed here https://help.sap.com/docs/cloud-transport-management/sap-cloud-transport-management/supported-content-types?locale=en-US 

example:

Step 2.2: create TransportManagementService destination 

And then, with the source node name, you can go to the source SBPA subaccount, and create a destination named TransportManagementService, pointing to the cTMS service instance, and specify the property to source node. This will allow you to perform Export from Content Agent UI, SAP Integration Suite UI, or SAP Build. Details see https://help.sap.com/docs/content-agent-service/user-guide/create-transportmanagementservice-destination

 

Step 2.3: add destination to SBPA source 

Now you can go to your source SBPA, in the control tower, you can add the TransportManagementService destination you created for cTMS service instance.

Step 3: Test the transport in SBPA

You can now test with the transport feature in SBPA.

Choose a project in SBPA, choose a release version, click the …, click Transport. 

In the source node, you need to choose the source node you created in the transport route in cTMS, and then give your description of the transport (if there are descriptions in your project, it will be automatically written). Then you can click Transport to start the process. 

The transport content will be packed as MTA to your cTMS source node, and you will see the tag “Transported” in your project release after success.

In your cTMS, you will see that your source node has transport event as succeeded. 

But in target node, you will need to first approve the transport request and then the content will be transported to your target SBPA. 

After succeeded, you can go to the target SBPA, and import the content as a project. First you will notice that there is a red notification icon displayed by import button, and then you click into it, you will find the available content. Choose it and click import, you will find it created as a project and you are the member of the project. 

This means that the transport of SBPA content via cTMS works.

Then you go to the second half of the post, to add the governance rule to transport.

Step 4: Create service instance, key, destination for source SBPA

From this step on, we will add the governance rule to transport. The architecture will eventually look like:

 

Step 4.1: Create service instance and service key for source SBPA

Create a service instance and service key for source SAP Build Process Automation. See https://help.sap.com/docs/build/sap-build-core/configure-governance-rules?locale=en-US

Then create a destination pointing to the SBPA service instance you just created, using the authentication type of OAuth2UserTokenExchange. This is where a token representing one user (e.g., a JWT from XSUAA) is exchanged for another token for the same user but for a different audience or scope. This is crucial in multi-tier applications where a service needs to call another service, maintaining the original user's identity.

Remember to add a property to the destination: sap.processautomation.enabled=true.

Also add the destination to the source SBPA's control tower:

Step 5: enable the Governance Rule for Transport

In SBPA's control tower, Governance Rules, find the template to create the governance rule for transport.

When you click into the process of the newly created project, you will see the approval flow, and you can adjust it. By default, there is a questionnaire sent to the person who trigger the transport process, and then the filled out questionnaire will be sent for the same person (can be adjusted to your need) for approval.

You will need to release it, deploy it in the environment of Governance, and to the destination you just created for the source SBPA service instance:

And last but not least, you go back to the control tower, governance rule, and enable it for transport:

You can also do the same for project creation.

Step 5: Test it with transport

In lobby, find a project to transport. You will need to choose a released version of it, and in the transport dialog that opens, enter the description and choose the source node.

You will see that the status of the release turns into “complete transport questionnaire” (it will change according to which step you are in the transport governance rule process). The popout window reminds you of a pending questionnaire, and you can go to the questionnaire from here or in the My Inbox.

Next step is to complete the questionnaire:

And approve the questionnaire:

And then the content will be transport by CAS to the source node in cTMS, and the rest of the steps will be familiar to you.

Approve in target node:

Go to the target SBPA and you will find the content transported there:

In the source SPBA, you can check the past transport requests in control tower:

entry.title: CREATION OF A BOT 'FILE NAME EXTRACTOR TO EXCEL' USING SAP BTP PROCESS AUTOMATION
entry.content:
The main objective of this Bot is to list and logs files into excel for recordkeeping.

So here are the steps to make this bot automation. 

In SAP Build lobby click on create option. 


After clicking create option, create object interface will open. We have to create automation, for this we have to select Automation Process and click Next.


Now we have to choose type, whether this automation is process type or automation type.

As you can see there are two options, that are, Process and automation.

Process: We have to choose Process when we need to build a business process to automate a workflow. Process is used in automation sales order, invoice management, approval flows.

Automation: We have to choose Automation when we need to automate any repetitive tasks across application. Automation is used in extracting data from documents, mass updates of data, local file management.

So, as per our bot we have to select Automation option.

 

           Name: Name Extractor to Excel
           Description: List and logs files into excel for record keeping purpose.
After filling this click on Review. 


Now click on Create


Now click on Create, then click on Automation.



Then we have to configure agent version.




Name: Name Extractor to Excel. Then click on Create.


Now click on setting icon, then click on Dependencies then add option.


Then click on add and then click on Add a Business Process Project Dependency. then add Excel SDK.


Now we will start building our automation by dragging activities from the pannel to the flow.
The activities we have to use for this automation are
                i) Get File Collection
               ii) Open Excel Instances
              iii) Add Workbook
              iv) Set Values (Cells)
               v) Save as Workbook

In get file collection activity, in folder path give the path of the folder which we have to show.
In set values (Cells) activity we have to define the cell ranges for excel sheet
   Values: Coll
In Save as Workbook activity, in file path give the path with the name of the excel sheet where we have to save the list of files in folder.

Save the flow.


Now test the automation.



Conclusion:
This bot will list out the files of a specified folder in an excel worksheet.  

Best Regards,
Smruti Rekha Pradhan

entry.title: Triggering Process in Shared Environments from SAP Build Apps
entry.content:
After this post was written, with the help of the wonderful community, we came up with a different, and in most ways, better solution for this issue. See https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-sap/triggering-process-in-shared-environment-from-sap-build-apps-better/ba-p/14183502.

But what's written in this blog is still valuable, because it will show you how to use the relatively new flow function HTTP Destination Request, which lets you easily and still with a good amount of control call APIs using destinations.

Unfortunately, the Processes flow functions to trigger processes from SAP Build Apps (for now) do not work for shared environments. And since the public environment is deprecated, that means they essentially no longer work at all.  Hopefully this will be modified soon.

In the meantime, here's how to work around that issue.

The Issue

I am not sure but I assume the issue is that when you make an API call to trigger a process in a shared environment, you must send the environment id as a query parameter.

/workflow/rest/v1/workflow-instances?environmentId=salesgroup

But the flow functions do not have an input for the environment, so they automatically try to trigger a process in the public (default) environment.

By the way, the identifier for an environment can be found when you open the environment in the Control Tower.

The Workaround

The good news is SAP Build Apps recently added a new flow function called HTTP Destination Request that lets us create a customized HTTP request but using a destination. That is we get the control we get from the HTTP Request flow function but with the ability to connect through a destination.

As a prerequisite you need to have a destination called sap_process_automation_service_user_access to the SAP Build Process Automation service, the same as if you wanted to use the Processes flow functions. This is described in the Processes documentation.

You will need to add the destination properties so that it appears in your SAP Build Apps project:

BuildApps.Enabled = true
BuildApps.ApiType = rest

To add the destination to your project:

  1. Go to the Integrations tab.
  2. Click Add Integration.                                                         
  3.  Click BTP Destinations.
  4. Select the destination.
  5. Click Install Integration.                      

If you go back to the Integrations tab main screen, you'll see the destination. That's all you need to do to add the destination to the project and make it available to your HTTP Destination Request flow function.

To trigger a process deployed to a shared environment, do the following:

  1. Add a button.
  2. In the logic canvas for the button, add an HTTP Destination Request, along with any Alert flow functions to show the result or error
  3. Select the HTTP Destination Request, and set the following in the Properties tab.
    Destinationsap_process_automation_service_user_access
    HTTP MethodPOST
    Request Body Typejson
    Request BodyThis depends on the proper request body for your process. More on this below.
    Path
    /workflow/rest/v1/workflow-instances?environmentId=<environment ID>

    Replace the placeholder with the identifier for your environment.

    Response Typetext

       

The flow function has 3 outputs.

  • The first if the call is successful and returns 2XX status code.
  • The second if the call is successfully transmitted and a response is received but returns a 4XX or 5XX status code.
  • The third if the call is unsuccessful and no response is received.  

Request Body

The request body is determined by checking the trigger for the process.

  1. Go to the Control Tower.
  2. Click Environments.
  3. Click your environment.
  4. Click Triggers.
  5. Click View next to the trigger for your process.

You will now see the payload for the API for that trigger. This will be the request body.

Note that you cannot copy from the box with the payload. You will have to use the copy button to copy the entire payload. Note also you can see the URL for the API, including the environmentId parameter you must pass.

The Upshot

The method above is pretty straight-forward and has the advantage of teaching you what is happening behind the scenes and how the SAP Build Process Automation APIs work. But I'll admit you lose the ease of use of the flow functions, and also the ability to create variables from the input and output schema of your processes.

entry.title: Integrating SAP SuccessFactors with SAP Build Process Automation via SAP Cloud Application Event Hub
entry.content:
Overview

SAP Build Process Automation is a low-code/no-code platform that enables users to automate business processes and tasks using visual drag-and-drop tools. It combines workflow automation, robotic process automation (RPA), and embedded AI capabilities to streamline processes and improve efficiency. 

SAP Cloud Application Event Hub offers a flexible solution to distribute business events across the SAP cloud landscape. This service supports SAP's strategic event-driven architecture initiative to create a well-defined, easily consumable and extensible ecosystem for exchanging SAP business events.

We are using the Personal Data Collection scenario as a use case for this blog. In SAP SuccessFactors Onboarding, the "Personal Data Collection" event refers to the process where new hires provide their personal details during the onboarding process. This step allows new hires to validate and, in some cases, update information pre-populated from the recruiting system. The event is triggered when a new hire accesses the "Provide Personal Details" section within the onboarding checklist. Read here for more details.

This blog walks through setting up integration between SAP SuccessFactors, SAP Build Process Automation(SBPA) and SAP Cloud Application Event Hub. With this setup, events like onboarding process step in SuccessFactors can trigger workflows in SBPA—enabling truly event-driven business automation. For more information on Success Factors events in Business Accelerator Hub read here.

The integration support was released from SAP Build in Q2 2025. For more details refer to the YouTube video Whats New in SAP Build – Q2 2025 Highlights and Blog What’s New in SAP Build Q2 2025 - Release Highlights.

Note : Integration of SAP Build Process Automation with SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud Edition and SAP S/4HANA Private Cloud Edition is also available with Event Mesh and Advanced Event Mesh. Here are the reference blogs Event Mesh and SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud Setup for SAP Build Process Automation and Configure SAP Enterprise Messaging for SAP S/4HANA On-Premise 2020 via Service Key.

Prerequisites

Before you begin, make sure the following are available:

    • SAP BTP Global and Subaccount Account access as administrator
    • Check that the Active BTP Subaccount has SAP Build Process Automation Subscription for standard plan.

    • Valid SAP SuccessFactors CLD Tenant ID 

Step 1: Set Up Entitlements & Subscriptions

In this step we will setup the required entitlements and subscriptions. We will add "SAP Cloud Application Event Hub" subscription to BTP Subaccount if not already added.

Go to BTP Subaccount -> Entitlements -> Edit

Click on "Add Service Plans"

Search the services with keyword "event" and select "SAP Cloud Application Hub" service , then choose the service plan "standard" and click on "Add 1 Service Plan"

 Click Save.

The SAP Cloud Application Event Hub Service is added in sometime. This can be verified also from the BTP Subaccount -> "Services" - > "Service Marketplace" -> SAP Cloud Application Event Hub tile.

Create a new Subscription by clicking on the "SAP Cloud Application Event Hub" tile -> Create button.

Select the Service “SAP Cloud Application Event Hub” and Plan “standard” and click on Create.

The subscription will be created in sometime. Click on “View Subscription”.

 In the BTP Subaccount “Instances and Subscriptions” -> Note that “SAP Cloud Application Event Hub” subscription is added with status as subscribed.

    • Add all the roles for the user for enterprise messaging. Refer to the details here.

Step 2: Register Your SuccessFactors System

In this step we will register the SuccessFactors system with the SAP BTP Subaccount, if its not already added. This step is needed to be able to discover events based on the connected system in the SAP Build. It enables SAP Cloud Application Event Hub to discover and communicate with your SFSF system.

    • Go to Systems in System Landscape in BTP Global Account
    • Switch to Service Owner View
    • Click on “Add System”.
      • Select System Type as Success Factors
      • Enter a valid system name or your CLD Tenant ID from SuccessFactors
      • Click on Add

    • Confirm the system appears in the list

Step 3: Create Eventing Formation

Eventing between SAP Cloud systems enables decoupled communication by exchanging events between applications. This approach allows systems to react to changes in other systems without direct dependencies, promoting flexibility and scalability. 

    •  Navigate to Global Account → System Landscape → Formations
    • In Customer View -> Click Create Formation

    • Select: Eventing between SAP Cloud Systems

    • Add the following systems in the Include Systems step of the wizard (IMPORTANT NOTE: All of them should be in the same BTP Subaccount):
      • Your registered SAP SuccessFactors system
      • The SAP Cloud Application Event Hub service (might also reflect as Event Broker)
      • Your SAP Build Process Automation tenant
    • Review the selection

    • Click Create and check that the formation is created successfully

Step 4: Add Integration Dependency

In the SAP BTP cockpit System Landscape, you need to define integration dependencies that describe the events you need to integrate with another system for a given scenario.

    •  Select the Formation created in the above step

Navigate to SAP Build Process Automation → Open in System Page

    • Click Integration Dependencies  -> Add

    • Fill in:
      • Template

      • Name: e.g., SF_Eventing
      • Publishing System Namespace:sap.sf
      • Event Type: (paste exactly from SF docs)

    • Review and Add

Check that the Integration Dependency is added

 Step 5: Create Integration Formation

The formation type "Integration with SAP Build" refers to a configuration within SAP BTP (Business Technology Platform) that enables the integration of SAP systems with the SAP Build suite, specifically for scenarios like process automation and application development. This formation type is used when you want to connect your SAP system (e.g., SAP Success Factors) to services like SAP Build Process Automation or other SAP Build solutions. 

    • Navigate to Global Account → System Landscape → Formations -> Customer View -> Click Create Formation

    • Give a formation name and Select: Integration with SAP Build

    • Add the following systems in the Include Systems step of the wizard (IMPORTANT NOTE: All of them should be in the same BTP Subaccount):
      • Your registered SAP SuccessFactors system
      • Your SAP Build tenant
    • Review the selection

    •  Click Create and check that the formation is created successfully

Step 6: Validate in Event Hub App

As SAP Build is a consumer of events, you need manage event subscriptions in the SAP Cloud Application Event Hub application. Integration dependencies defined in the System Landscape become available as event subscriptions.

Pre-requisite : Assign relevant Event Broker Roles to your user, if roles were just assigned, re-login.

    • Open the Event Hub Application

 Click on “All Available Subscriptions” and select the subscription name that we have created in the above step.

 Enable the SFSF event subscription.

Click on Enable.

Check that the Subscription status is “Active”.

Step 7: Create and publish an events project

Now you need to create an event project from the SAP Build Lobby which will be published to Library so that we can use it as an event trigger in the SBPA process. Follow the steps mentioned below:

  • Create an event project. Go to the SAP BTP Sub Account -> Lobby -> Connectors ->Events ->Create.

  • As the Success Factors system and BTP Subaccount are now connected and we will be able to choose events based on the connected systems, choose Unified Customer Landscape.

Note: Read Discovering Business Events from Lobby for SAP Build Process Automation : Manage Credit Memo Request for more ways to create Event Projects from SAP Build Lobby.

Select SAP SuccessFactors Onboarding Events.

Select Onboarding Process Step.

Review all the events and payloads and click on Add.

Create the event project. Release and publish it to the library. Note : Publishing is mandatory to be able to use the events as event trigger in any SBPA Process.

After the event project is created successfully, its listed in the Lobby.

Step 8: Create and Deploy a Sample process in SAP Build Process Automation

    • Go to SAP Build Process Automation from the BTP Subaccount
    • Create a new Process Project,  the empty process would look like the following.

    • Click on Add a trigger ->  “Wait for an Event” from the trigger options to add an event trigger to the project.

  • Search and Add the required event from the library.

After creation of event trigger check that the event trigger is added and the Outputs tab shows the event payload.  This payload can be further used in the business process for further processing like approvals, decisions, subprocesses , actions etc.

    • Add a simple action (e.g., approval or email) or any set of actions required for your business process. A sample process could look like the following.

    • Release and Deploy the process by selecting appropriate environment.
    • Test by triggering the event from Success Factors.

The below step confirms that the Personal Data Collection is completed and this event should now trigger our deployed SBPA Process.

 Go to SAP BTP Subaccount -> Lobby -> Monitoring -> Process and Workflow Instances and check that the process is in Running status.

 You can open the process instance to see further details. For example, in the below logs the task is waiting to be approved in My Inbox.

 Click My Inbox to review and approve the task.

 Note that the simple approval process based on SuccessFactors event is completed.

 Below is the sample Logs view for the completed process instance.

Troubleshooting Tips

    • If systems aren’t showing in formations: double-check region/subaccount match
    • Event Hub app not showing dependencies? Check your user role + re-login
    • Not receiving events? Confirm SuccessFactors is emitting the specific event (some are tenant-configurable). Also check the section Lobby -> Monitoring -> Acquired Events -> Business Events to confirm that business events are received in SBPA.

Conclusion

You’ve now connected SAP SuccessFactors to SAP Build via SAP Cloud Application Event Hub! This architecture lays the groundwork for robust, event-driven automations—like onboarding workflows—all without writing complex integration code or going through complicated setup process.

References

Please refer to the below blogs for event driven architecture in SAP Build Process Automation:

Business Event Triggers in SAP Build Process Automation for SAP S/4HANA Cloud : The Customer Return (BKP) Use Case

Business Event Triggers in SAP Build Process Automation for SAP S/4HANA: Manage Billing Block on Sales Orders

Business Event Triggers in SAP Build Process Automation for SAP S/4HANA: Manage Credit Block on Sales Orders

Discovering Business Events from Lobby for SAP Build Process Automation : Manage Credit Memo Request

Event Mesh and SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud Setup for SAP Build Process Automation
Incorporating Custom Events from Lobby into SAP Build Process Automation

Thanks to my co-author @emanuil_ivanov  for his valuable support and collaboration for the content of this blog !

entry.title: SAP BTP Hackathon at SAPHILA 2025: Celebrating the Winners and Innovation in Action
entry.content:
A few months ago, we shared our excitement about the launch of the first-ever SAP BTP Hackathon in Africa in joined collaboration of AFSUG and SAP, highlighting the unique opportunity it offered for AFSUG members to bring their creativity and problem-solving skills to the forefront of the SAP community. Now, with the event behind us, it’s time to reflect on what unfolded and celebrate the teams and ideas that made this inaugural Hackathon truly special.

From Ideation to Demo Jam: A Journey of Collaboration

As outlined in the previous blog, the hackathon was more than just a competition, it was a journey. Eighteen teams, representing a broad cross-section of AFSUG members, embarked on an eight-week sprint, supported by SAP BTP experts and coaches. The focus was on building real-world solutions using SAP BTP components like SAP Build, SAP HANA Cloud, SAP Integration Suite and ABAP Cloud amongst other SAP BTP based Services & Solutions.

After intensive enablement and development sessions, three teams emerged as finalists and were invited to present their solutions live at SAPHILA 2025’s Demo Jam. The energy in the room was palpable as each team showcased how SAP BTP could be harnessed to solve pressing business challenges.

And the Winner Is… PwC South Africa!

In a closely contested finale, the SAPHILA audience voted PwC South Africa as the overall winner for their AI-driven legal services platform “Legal Ease”. This solution stood out for its innovative use of AI to simplify legal document processing and understanding, a pain point for many businesses and consumers alike. “Legal Ease” enables users to scan and summarize complex contracts, ask questions in natural language, and receive clear, actionable insights. The platform even supports translation into local languages and integrates with knowledge bases for related services.

What impressed both the jury and the audience was not just the technical sophistication, but the clear business value: “Legal Ease” addresses real frustrations around contract transparency, billing and accessibility, with the potential to transform how legal services are delivered in Africa and beyond.

Honouring the Finalists: Debswana Diamond Company and Bell Equipment

Let’s not forget the other two finalists, who also delivered outstanding solutions:

  • Debswana Diamond Company tackled overtime management with an AI-powered assistant that streamlines scheduling, reduces costs and supports employee well-being.
  • Bell Equipment automated shipment tracking and document processing, helping to prevent stock shortages and improve logistics efficiency.

Both teams demonstrated the breadth of innovation possible with SAP BTP and set a high bar for future Hackathons.

Reflections and What’s Next

The Hackathon’s main objective was to foster deep collaboration between SAP and its customers, giving local teams a hands-on opportunity to explore and build with SAP BTP. The quality and diversity of solutions, especially the creative use of AI and automation, highlight the immense potential within the African SAP community.

Amanda Gibbs, CEO of AFSUG, summed it up perfectly:

“It is inspiring to witness what can be achieved in just eight weeks using SAP BTP;

we’ve seen incredible progress and innovation.”

Join the Conversation

Congratulations again to all teams who participated and especially to PwC South Africa for their winning solution! If you were inspired by the SAP BTP Hackathon or have thoughts on how SAP BTP can drive innovation in your organization, I’d love to hear from you in the comments.

And if you missed out this year, keep an eye out for future SAP BTP Hackathons - this is just the beginning!

entry.title: Unlock SAP Joule for Developers—Claim Your Free Access Today
entry.content:
Try SAP Joule for Developers—Now Available for Free 

We have recently introduced powerful new Joule capabilities for developers across SAP Build Code, SAP Build Process Automation, SAP Build Apps, and ABAP environment. These AI features are designed to accelerate development, boost productivity, and bring intelligence into the tools you already use. 

Now’s the perfect time to try them. SAP Joule for Developers is available for free. Once the free offer ends, a commercial model based on AI Units will apply—so don’t miss this opportunity to explore what’s possible with AI in your SAP development tools. 

 Quick reminder: A valid license for SAP Build or ABAP is required to use the AI capabilities in those environments. 

 

What is SAP Joule for Developers? 

Announced on March 18, SAP Joule for Developers is a package of embedded AI capabilities powered by Joule and available within: 

  • SAP Build Code 
  • SAP Build Process Automation 
  • SAP Build Apps 
  • ABAP Environment 

These tools now help you generate code from natural language, automate processes faster, and build apps more efficiently—all with AI integrated directly into the experience. 

We’ll walk through the setup steps in an upcoming section. But first, here are some helpful resources to catch up on the latest: 

  • Read the Announcement
  • Explore the Technical Overview
  • Check out the FAQs

 

Customer Success

See how early adopters are already transforming their work with SAP Joule for Developers: 

“Joule for Developers dramatically boosts productivity by enabling developers to quickly generate enterprise-grade apps, including logic, data models, sample data, and test scripts. It serves as a virtual guide to assist developers during design-time and helps resolve local testing exceptions efficiently.” — Gerard Van Paassen, CEO at Aarini Consulting 

“Joule for Developers not only generates data models but also makes it simple to design Fiori UIs and enrich test data—resulting in a major productivity boost across our development lifecycle.” — Michael Brand, Senior Consultant at FIS 

“PwC uses Joule for Developers in SAP Build to rapidly deliver innovative SAP solutions. Its generative AI supercharges our developers’ output, helping us accelerate award-winning ESG solutions while extending SAP S/4HANA and other enterprise apps—without compromising the clean core.” — Dr. Nicholas Nicoloudis, Global Head of SAP Innovation at PwC 

From accelerating application generation to streamlining code optimization, customers are seeing measurable time savings, higher productivity, and better quality in their SAP extension development projects. 

Stay tuned as we share more customer experiences—yours could be next. Try SAP Joule for Developers today while it’s free. 

 

Activate AI capabilities in SAP Build: 

Now, let’s walk through how to enable the AI capabilities in SAP Build. 

Note: AI capabilities in SAP Build Code have already been enabled and available for use in the environment. The instructions below applies to SAP Build Process Automation and SAP Build Apps. 

1. On the Build homepage, click Control Tower in the left-hand navigation panel. 

 2. Select Generative AI from the settings canvas. 

 3. Toggle the Enable Generative AI button 

 4. Read and accept the SAP AI Terms 

 5. Verify that the AI features are enabled 

 

 

Activate AI capabilities in ABAP Environment: 

Note: For existing customers, they will need to reorder the $0 SKU to continue using the ABAP AI capabilities.

 

A. For Customers: 

1. Contact your Account Executive to purchase the SAP Joule for Developers, ABAP AI capabilities license (SKU ID: 8019124). The AE will create an order containing the license material. 

2. Once the purchase is complete, ABAP development systems will be enabled for ABAP AI capabilities within 48 hours. 

3. To start using Joule capabilities in ABAP, ensure you have the required authorizations. For details, see the documentation and screenshot below.

 

B. For Partners: 

1. Get the TDD ABAP AI capabilities license (SKU ID 8019541):  

  • Go to Manage My Services App 
  • Add the SKU to an existing order, e.g. Pay-as-you-go (see screenshots below). 

2. Once the purchase is complete, ABAP development systems will be enabled for ABAP AI capabilities within 48 hours. 

3. To start using Joule capabilities in ABAP, ensure you have the required authorizations. For details, see the documentation and screenshot below.

 

Start leveraging the power of AI today!  

Enable SAP Joule for Developers and experience a significant boost in your development efficiency. Don't miss out on the free offer! 

 #SAPJouleForDevelopers #SAPBuild #ABAPCloud #SAPBusinessTechnologyPlatform

entry.title: Triggering Process in Shared Environment from SAP Build Apps - Better Solution 😸
entry.content:
In my previous blog post Triggering Process in Shared Environments from SAP Build Apps,  I showed you how to trigger from SAP Build Apps a process that was deployed to a shared environment  -- using HTTP Destination Request instead of Processes flow functions.

Though I thought it was pretty easy -- and I liked it because I could control the API call and see what was going on under the hood -- it still required me to know the APIs as well as to give up on some of the cool SAP Build Apps capabilities that come with the Processes flow functions (like automatic generation of schemas from inputs/outputs of a process).

Thanks to @KuroKen, I discovered a better way, who commented on my original post.

At first I struggled to get the solution to work, even though I was assured it worked. But as usual, the struggling was good and revealed all kinds of additional nuances about the system (see Issues below). After 2 weeks of study, here's my explanation of this solution.

The Problem (reminder)

SAP Build Apps has a wonderful set of flow functions that makes it easy to trigger processes (and run other SAP Build Process Automation APIs). 

But the problem is that they were developed before SAP Build environments was a big thing, and certainly before the Public environment was deprecated. The API to trigger a process in a shared environment requires a query parameter specifying the environment, but the flow functions do not include this parameter and therefore the flow function can only trigger Public processes, which as we said are deprecated.

🙀

The Solution

Well, it is pretty simple -- don't require the query parameter.

But how?

When creating the SAP Build Process Automation instance in the SAP BTP cockpit, you can add a small configuration  that will assign that instance to a specific shared environment so you will not have to pass the environment name when you call the API.

To set up SAP Build Process Automation, you need to create an instance of the service. In the cockpit click Create.

You select SAP Build Process Automation, and select the standard instance plan. 

Instead of clicking Create, click Next so you can add a configuration to specify a shared environment to connect to this instance. In the dialog, you enter an environment ID and an API key with rights to trigger processes and more.

The following is the dialog where you post your configuration:

The following is an example of the JSON to set (you need to replace with your own environment ID and API key):

{
    "environmentId": "salesgroup",
    "apiKey": "fPdjgABCD-wZUckjh-c6e2wFyU3SgL"
}

 If you already have an instance, you can run Update and then supply the JSON.

Some of this process is described here: https://help.sap.com/docs/build-process-automation/sap-build-process-automation/update-service-instance

Environment ID

The environment ID can be found when you go to Control Tower and open your environment, under Identifier.

API Key

Within the environment, you can go to the API Keys tab and create a new API key.

For the key you must give it enough scope for triggering processes, specifically the environment_read, trigger_read and trigger_execute scopes.

 

How You Trigger Process from SAP Build Apps

Now that we have overcome the problem with shared environments, here's a quick review of how to trigger a process from SAP Build Apps.

  1. Publish your deployed process project.
  2.  In SAP Build Apps, go to Integrations > Add Integration > Library, and select the process you want to expose from within the deployed project (which should appear since the project was published). Click Enable Process. 
  3. In the logic canvas (perhaps in response to a button), drag in a Processes > Trigger Process flow function. 
  4. In the flow function, specify the process to trigger and the inputs for the process.

 

Issues

The main issue was that I was using a destination with OAuth2JWTBearer (user authentication). The above works currently only for OAuth2ClientCredentials. So when @KuroKen explained his solution, I didn't understand because it didn't work for me, and he must of thought I was incompetent or crazy.

I contacted development and they confirmed that I was not crazy, that in fact there was a bug -- the client credentials and user token authentication flows used different flows and the one for user tokens had a bug. My understanding is that that bug was fixed and is awaiting deployment. As always,, no guarantees

Potential pitfall

This solution works like a charm, and restores all the great capabilities of SAP Build Apps flow functions. And as long as long as there are only a few environments, it should work pretty well.

But let's say I have 3 environments, and I create 3 instances of SAP Build Process Automation, each will require its own destination to define the connection from SAP Build Apps. But SAP Build Apps assumes the name of the destination is sap_process_automation_service_user_access. So in a  case where I want to trigger processes in different environments from my app, I think I would have a problem -- though I do not know how common a use case that would be.

I am told that there is no cost or performance issue for creating multiple instances, so that is good.

I assume that I can override the configuration by sending the query parameter for another environment, but I have not tested this.

Hope this helps,

😸

entry.title: Calling SAP AI Core Orchestration v2 API from SAP Build: A Quick Fix Guide
entry.content:
Hey folks,

Just wanted to share a quick post about a recent issue I ran into while working with SAP Build Actions and SAP AI Core’s Orchestration v2 API — specifically the completion endpoint. This will be a short and to-the-point blog post for anyone hitting similar roadblocks trying to configure an action in SAP Build to call this API.

Let me break it down into three parts:

1. The Problem

I was trying to configure an SAP Build action to call the /completion method from the SAP AI Core Orchestration v2 API.

Now, normally this is quite straightforward — just grab the API specification JSON file from the SAP Business Accelerator Hub and upload it using the SAP Build wizard. But in this case, things didn’t go as planned.

Here’s what happened:

  • The completion method didn’t show up in the wizard.
  • I tried uploading the API spec file manually — this time it showed the method. Great!
  • But once I used the provided example from the API doc to test it, I got hit with a 400 error 😑



2. Why the Standard Way Doesn’t Work

Turns out, the schema and the example JSON in the API documentation don’t match. So even though the wizard technically accepts the API file, SAP Build complains when you try to use the provided example.

From what I observed, it looks like the schema or example might have been copied from v1 or has some leftover data that doesn’t match v2 requirements. Either way — we’re stuck unless we intervene manually.

3. The Fix: Manual Configuration & Correct Payload

Since I couldn’t rely on the official schema and example, I took a more DIY approach.

Step 1: Clean up the payload

First, I stripped down the example JSON to just the mandatory fields to pass SAP Build’s schema validation. That helped temporarily, but when I actually hit the API, I got a new error saying:

"Missing required field: orchestration_config"

So, clearly the schema itself was also incomplete.

❗Quick Detour: Tried AI Launchpad for Help

At this point, I thought of checking the SAP AI Launchpad in BTP to get the real orchestration configuration JSON. That would be the natural place to find the actual payload, right?

But unfortunately, the orchestration config shown in AI Launchpad of subaccount is identical to what was already in the API specification file — so no luck there either. 😅


Step 2: Find a correct schema

Luckily, I found this tutorial which had a bruno_collection file. I searched for the completion method and found the json schema with the orchestration_config keyword included.

 


Here's a snippet:

{
  "orchestration_config": {
    "module_configurations": {
      "grounding_module_config": {
        ...
      },
      ...
    }
  },
  "input_params": {
    "groundingRequest": "what is joule?"
  },
  "return_module_results": true
}


Step 3: Configure SAP Build

At this point, you can either remove the action and

  • Build from scratch
  • Or continue with the existing action and replace the faulty input key with the corrected one


If you face a similar issue with output structure, you can follow the same logic — update the output schema manually to match the real response you’re getting.

And finally… 💥

It works! 🎉


Final Thoughts

So, if you’re trying to call the SAP AI Core Orchestration v2 /completion API from SAP Build and the standard flow isn’t working — don’t worry. It’s not you, it’s the schema 😉

You’ll likely need to:

  • Skip the API wizard
  • Use the correct payload from the tutorial
  • Manually configure your action with fixed request and response schemas

Let me know in the comments if you ran into the same issue or found a better workaround! I’d love to learn how you approached it too.

Thanks for reading 🙌

entry.title: 🟡 Fun for Week 1: The Devtoberfest Scavenger Hunt 🔨🪙
entry.content:
Welcome to the Devtoberfest Scavenger Hunt, a chase around important SAP developer-related tools/sites, a challenge to construct a secret phrase, and a chance to win 1000s of points toward the Devtoberfest grand prize.

The hunt officially starts Sept. 25, with the release of the first clue during that day's SAP Developer News, and you have until the end of Devtoberfest, Oct. 24, to complete it.

To get all the clues make sure to SUBSCRIBE TO THIS POST!!

Learn more about the  entire Devtoberfest event in @KevinR's post Devtoberfest 2025 Welcome!.

What you need to find

We have hidden a special phrase, which you need to figure out using the clues from several missions, described in the next section. Along your journey you will do the following:

  1. Visit about 10 different locations related to SAP developers, mostly web sites that are designed to help you in your daily SAP development.
  2. At each location, you will discover a set of hexadecimal digits.
  3. Concatenate the digits together (in the order of the missions) to get one, 37-digit hexadecimal number.
  4. Multiply that hexadecimal number by another secret number, for which we will give a clue.
  5. Take the resulting 38-digit hexadecimal product, and convert it into the secret phrase, using each pair of digits as values for ASCII characters.
  6. Enter the phrase, exactly (case-sensitive, no extra spaces), into the Scavenger Hunt tutorial.‌

Not until the SAP Developer News of Oct. 16 will you have all the pieces to be able to complete the phrase. 

Example Hunt

As an example of what you will have to do, here's a short sample hunt (just a warm-up, no points will be earned). Each mission is independent of the other.

MissionNo. DigitsSAP Web PropertyInstructions
17

SAP Developers YouTube Channel

Go to our SAP Developer YouTube channel. 

Open @Rekha_DR's video "SAP Build Process Automation (Part 1): Build your very first process". Watch it and find the secret 7-digit hexadecimal number in one of the info cards.

You can also see the hex digits in the description.

26SAP Community

Inside this blog post, use the Developer Tools on your browser to inspect the words "SAP Community" in the cell immediately to the left (in this very table) and find the 6-digit RGB ASCII code for the color of the text. 

3None (directly) 

Concatenate the 2 sets of hexadecimal digits (13 in all), in order, and multiply the resulting hexadecimal number by the number of original SAP founders (you can easily find the number on the SAP Wikipedia page).

Convert the resulting hexadecimal number into a phrase, converting each pair of digits into a character using ASCII codes.

👉In this blog post, post a comment/picture about the phrase -- but NOT the phrase itself  (like your experiences with or opinion about the phrase, or a picture of something belonging to you that reminds you of the phrase). You won't get any points, but it will be fun and you will be ready for the real scavenger hunt. If you have any trouble with this example hunt, post in the comments.

REMINDER: The above is just an example of how the real scavenger hunt will work. The real scavenger hunt instructions will be described in the rest of this blog post, as clues become available.

 

The (real) hunt

Below are the instructions for finding the hexadecimal digits for the actual scavenger hunt. We will release clues as follows:

  • In the SAP Developer News of Sept. 25, Oct. 2, Oct. 9, and Oct. 16.
  • In this blog each Monday during the first 3 weeks of Devtoberfest.

👉To be notified when a new clue is released, SUBSCRIBE TO THIS POST!!

‌ When you find the secret phase, just enter it into this Devtoberfest tutorial.

To guide you, we have created a second tutorial -- you do not have to use it, nor do you get any points from it. But you can enter the 1 to 6 digits from each mission to check if you received the correct digits for that mission.

Here are your missions 

MissionNo. DigitsSAP Web PropertyInstructions
12

SAP Developer News

The Developer News comes out each Thursday with the latest about ABAP, CAP, BTP, SAP Build, UI5, Fiori, AI, and all your favorite SAP developer topics. All delivered by some of your favorite Developer Advocates, like DJ, Shilpa Shankar, Thomas Jung, Antonio Maradiaga, Nora von Thenen and the rest of the gang.

Most episodes about 5 minutes. Also available as a Podcast.

Watch the Developer News of Sept. 25 for this mission's clue 
26 To be released Sept. 29
34 To be released Sept. 29
42 To be released Oct. 2 (check out this week's Developer News)
54 To be released Oct. 6
66 To be released Oct. 6
76 To be released Oct. 9 (check out this week's Developer News)
86 To be released Oct. 13
91 To be released Oct. 13
10None (directly) To be released Oct. 16 (check out this week's Developer News)

Good luck!

😸

entry.title: Deep Dive and Experience Sharing into SAP Joule for Developers(J4D)
entry.content:
Disclaimer: This blog is not written by any LLM.

Well, to start with, Joule for Developers, let us understand what it is?

Many people have a misconception that Joule for Developers or J4D is just an ABAP AI capability. But it is much more beyond ABAP. Joule for Developers(J4D) is collective name for the AI-powered design-time capabilities across SAP Build and ABAP

It includes new and existing features enabled by Joule in:

  1. SAP Build Code
  2. SAP Build Apps
  3. SAP Build Process Automation
  4. ABAP in SAP BTP and S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition

These capabilities help developers build faster, code smarter, and automate better. Is that true? I will my honest opinion for some of them.

I have personally worked on SAP Build Apps, SAP Build Code and Joule for Developers, ABAP AI. I started with a lot of ambiguity and finally I made a mark that I could now explain it to our customers and users.

SAP Build Apps allow for generating pages to handle data entities and generate sample data automatically. It means, whenever you integrate any oData service/REST API/SAP BTP Destination, you get an option to automatically create the User Interface and also generate sample data.

SAP Build Code, has evolved through multiple iterations and seems it is still evolving. 

  • Created Fiori element app using Image
  • Created a series of projects with prompts
  • Created test data

With ABAP AI, I could create a report with the suggestions popping up in run time and that too contextually aware code prompts also known to be predictive code completion feature. We called it Ghost Code. But trust me sometimes they are really good too. 

I see the ABAP and CDS unit scripts getting generated in no time. It was good again on this parameter. 

Code explain, well I created small projects, hence feel it is good to have comments. But the true colors will be visible when you look at the repository of thousands lines of code written by someone and you have no clue of what it is. Using your skills you debug the code to understand what each block/function is doing. It is a life saver in this scenario.

SAP Build Code has the GenAI embedded as part of the service itself. There is no explicit step which need to perform other than just subscribing to this service via the Boosters (from the SAP BTP Global Account).

For SAP Build Apps and SAP Build Process Automation, everything under the new SAP Build Offering, will have the GenAI capability turned off by default. Then, how do you turn it on?

  1. Go to your SAP BTP Subaccount and access the SAP Build Apps and SAP Build Process Automation service from the 'Instances and Subscription' option
  2. SAP Build Lobby will openStep 1 - Access SAP Build Lobby

  3. Now go to the 'Control Tower' in the right hand side panel, last option and then click on the 'Generative AI' tile in the top row, right hand side 'Tenant Configuration'Step 2 - Click on Control Tower Option in Left Hand Pane

  4. Switch on the toggle button of Generative AI
    Step 3 - Click on Generative AI tile in the right hand pane

  5. Read the AI Terms and Conditions and scroll to the bottom of the Terms and Conditions to enable the checkbox of 'I have read the terms and conditions' - this is called as 'Scroll wrap agreement' in the language of Law - it means you agree to the Terms and Conditions and read till the last of the agreement.

    Step 5 - Read/Scroll to the end of the AI Terms & Conditions

  6. Click on the checkbox of 'I have read the terms and conditions'  

    Step 6 - Click on 'Accept' button on the right hand bottom corner

  7. Now click on the 'Accept' button 

    Step 4 - Turn on the toggle of Enable Generative AI features

  8. That's it. Now you can explore the GenAI capability inside SAP Build Apps and SAP Build Process Automation.

Some people have questions whether they need to sign a 0 USD AI Terms and Conditions contract to activate the GenAI capability for J4D. The answer is, except for 'Joule for Developers ABAP AI' capability, you do NOT need to sign an explicit contract for AI Terms and Conditions. They are all embedded within the services.

Well this will be an evolving document, where I will keep updating my reviews on each of these services mentioned. Stay tuned!

entry.title: Leveraging SAP Reference Architecture for Event-Driven Application in Missing Part Fulfilment Busine
entry.content:
Introduction

In the era of Industry 4.0, the ability to respond to real-time events in industrial production is crucial for operational efficiency. This blog outlines a proof of concept (PoC) that demonstrates how Airbus leveraged SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP), SAP Build Process Automation (BPA), and Events-to-Business Actions Framework to automate and orchestrate the missing part fulfillment process within production operations. The solution leverages an event-driven architecture to automate business processes based on missing part fulfillment in real-time.

This architecture is highly repeatable and can be applied to a wide range of SAP scenarios such as plant maintenance, purchase requisitions, inventory updates, and more, making it a valuable reference for enterprises looking to scale event-driven integrations. 

Engagement

The outcome described in this article was facilitated by custom adaptation of the Events-to-Business-Actions Framework by Airbus and was supported by SAP OCTO Team under PVN Pavankumar

Business Scenario : Missing Part Fulfilment in Production

The use case centres on streamlining the missing part fulfilment process within Airbus production operations. It begins when a missing part is detected for a work order reservation in the SAP ECC backend, which supports day-to-day production activities. From that initial identification, the process continues all the way through to the confirmation of the work order operation.

Throughout this journey, the workflow leverages an event-driven architecture (EDA) to track progress in real time, integrating seamlessly with backend systems. SAP Build Process Automation (BPA) orchestrates collaboration between all involved actors by sending out forms and notifications, gathering approvals, and automating decisions based on predefined business rules. Additionally, the PoC highlights the real-time monitoring and dashboarding features of SAP Build Process Automation, ensuring end-to-end visibility across the process.

This PoC showcases how we made that happen. 

Solution Architecture

Below is the architecture diagram representing the technical landscape for the missing part fulfilment process.

Figure 1: End-to-end architecture of the Airbus missing part fulfillment solution using SAP BTP, Advanced Event Mesh, E2B Framework, and custom Node.js applications.

Technical Implementation 

This architecture leverages key components across SAP BTP, Advanced Event Mesh, and custom applications to create a robust event-to-action pipeline: The Solution Architecture is illustrated in Figure 1, and the important components along with their connectivity are explained below:

-> Business events are triggered:
Different actors interact with the SAP backend (supporting production operations). Transactions such as work order reservations, purchase orders, or outbound deliveries generate relevant business events.

-> Events are routed to SAP Integration Suite, Advanced Event Mesh (AEM):
These events are sent to SAP Integration Suite, Advanced Event Mesh—either directly or via Solace event brokers in Airbus Private Cloud, especially if events need to be shared with other platforms.

->  Event-specific queues manage the flow:
Within SAP Integration Suite, Advanced Event Mesh, specific queues collect events related to predefined topics, pushing them into the Events to Business Actions (E2B) framework.

->  Business logic and workflows are triggered:
E2B calls SAP Build Process Automation (BPA) APIs to:

  • Apply decision rules and determine what business action should occur based on the event payload,
  • Launch new workflow instances,
  • Update waiting tasks on running workflows,
  • Push events to visibility scenarios for process monitoring.

->  Backend queries for richer context:
E2B also calls backend APIs to fetch more information related to business objects—such as:

  • Details of a reservation linked to a purchase order,
  • The specific station tied to a work order reservation,
  • The list of actors involved, leveraging Responsibility Management in SAP S/4HANA based on attributes like station.

->  Traceability with PartsNow:
PartsNow, is a custom SAP Cloud Application Programming (CAP,Node.js) application, used to persist the relationship between workflow instance IDs and related work order reservation IDs. E2B registers new workflow instances and can retrieve instance details as needed via PartsNow APIs.

->  Unified user experience in SAP Build Workzone:
SAP Build Workzone serves as the entry point for business actors, providing:

  • My Inbox: For completing tasks such as form fills or approvals,
  • My Processes: For real-time workflow monitoring,
  • Process Visibility Dashboard: To track KPIs and process efficiency,
  • Studio Home: Where process specialists can manage BPA decision rules.

->  Automated notifications and integration points:
Finally, SAP BPA calls remote APIs to:

  • Inform the PartsNow app about workflow instance completion,
  • Send email notifications to relevant actors via an SMTP server.

 

Developer Insights

As a developer building this PoC, a few key learnings stand out:

  • Loose coupling using SAP Integration Suite, Advanced Event Mesh and queues ensures resiliency and scalability.
  • Decision capability in SAP Build Process Automation allowed us to externalize complex logic from the app code, making it easier to maintain and extend.
  • Using SAP BTP Destinations and Service Bindings helped standardize secure backend access across environments.

Deployment Steps

Follow this GitHub documentation for detailed steps for configuration and deployment.

 

Closing Remarks
