We hope this blog has inspired new ideas for applying event-driven automation to your own business processes.

Refer to SAP Architecture Centre and Events-to-Business-Actions Framework Repository for implementation details. 

Thanks to colleagues from SAP OCTO Team Praveen Kumar Padegal and Swati Maste for their support.

entry.title: From Text to Process to Automation
entry.content:
A hands-on guide to transforming process descriptions into executable workflows with SAP Signavio and SAP Build Process Automation

Introduction

Many organizations still describe their business processes in plain text – whether in Word documents, emails, or even as spoken notes. What if you could turn these unstructured descriptions into documented BPMN 2.0 processes and then directly bring them to life in an automation platform?

With SAP Signavio’s Text to Process (currently available for free in the SAP Signavio Lab Space) and SAP Build Process Automation, you can do exactly that. In this post, I’ll walk you through the journey: from raw text to a documented process, and finally to an automation project.

I also created a video to show you the steps in the system.

Step 1: Start with your process description

The first thing you need is a textual description of your process.

  • If you already have written documentation, you’re good to go.

  • If not, you can dictate your process and use transcription software (or even built-in voice-to-text features on your device) to generate the description from your voice.

This step ensures you capture the real process knowledge in natural language before formalizing it.

If you want to test it here is a example: 

Example Procure to Pay

1. Purchase Requisition Creation

The process begins when an end user identifies a business need and creates a purchase requisition in the SAP Materials Management module. The requisitioner enters material specifications, quantities, delivery dates, cost centers, and preferred vendor information. The SAP system automatically generates a unique purchase requisition number for tracking purposes.

2. Purchase Requisition Approval

The purchase requisition routes to the designated approving manager through the SAP system. The approver reviews the requisition for business justification, budget availability, and policy compliance using the Materials Management module. Upon approval, the system updates the requisition status to released for further processing.

3. Source Determination and Vendor Selection

The purchasing department receives the approved requisition and begins vendor selection using the Materials Management module. Buyers analyze existing contracts, pricing agreements, and vendor performance to determine the most suitable supplier. They may initiate quotation processes if required to compare multiple vendor proposals.

4. Purchase Order Creation

The buyer creates a purchase order in SAP Materials Management, referencing the approved requisition. They enter complete vendor information, material specifications, quantities, prices, delivery terms, and payment conditions. The system generates a unique purchase order number and links it to the original requisition.

5. Purchase Order Approval

The purchase order undergoes approval by a purchasing manager or authorized personnel using the SAP system. The approver validates compliance with procurement policies, contract terms, and authorization limits. Following approval, the system changes the purchase order status to released, making it legally binding.

6. Purchase Order Transmission

The SAP system transmits the approved purchase order to the vendor through configured communication channels such as EDI, email, or print. The purchasing department monitors transmission and follows up to ensure vendor acknowledgment and order confirmation.

7. Goods Receipt Processing

Upon delivery, warehouse personnel physically receive and inspect the goods, then record the goods receipt in SAP Materials Management. They verify quantities and quality against the purchase order. The system automatically updates inventory levels, creates material documents, and posts accounting entries to relevant general ledger accounts.

8. Invoice Receipt and Verification

Accounts payable personnel enter the vendor invoice into SAP using the Materials Management and Financial Accounting modules. The system performs three-way matching, comparing the invoice against the purchase order and goods receipt to verify quantities, prices, and terms. Any discrepancies are flagged for resolution.

10. Invoice Approval

If required by company policy, the invoice undergoes additional approval using SAP Financial Accounting or workflow functionality. The approver validates the invoice for accuracy, authorization, and business validity before releasing it for payment processing.

11. Payment Processing

Accounts payable or treasury staff process payments using SAP Financial Accounting by including approved invoices in payment runs. The system considers payment terms and due dates to generate payment proposals, create payment documents, initiate bank transfers, and update vendor and cash accounts accordingly.

12. Payment Confirmation and Reconciliation

Treasury personnel process bank confirmations and perform reconciliation using SAP Financial Accounting. They verify successful payment transmission, match bank statements against system records, and investigate any discrepancies to ensure accurate cash position reporting.

Step 2: Convert text into a BPMN 2.0 process with SAP Signavio

Next, copy and paste your text into the Text to Process AI feature in SAP Signavio Lab Space.

Important: The Lab Space allows you to test innovative features like this for free, making it the perfect playground.

 

 

Step 3: Optimize and refine the process in SAP Signavio Process Manager

Once the BPMN diagram is generated, open it in SAP Signavio Process Manager to refine it.

Currently (as of September 2025), gateways are not automatically generated by the Text to Process feature. You’ll need to add them manually, along with any other adjustments needed to make the process executable and well-structured.

This step ensures your process is not just captured, but business-ready.

Step 4: Export the process as XML

After refining the diagram, you can export the BPMN model as an XML file.

  • In Signavio Process Manager, use the Export option.

  • Choose the BPMN 2.0 XML format, which is compatible with SAP Build Process Automation.

Step 5: Import into SAP Build Process Automation

Finally, switch over to SAP Build Process Automation.

  • Go to your project workspace.

  • Use the Import function to upload the XML file.

  • The BPMN structure will appear as the foundation for your automation project.

From here, you can define tasks, automate steps with bots, integrate with SAP or non-SAP systems, and turn your documented workflow into a living automation.

1) 

2)

3)

4) 

5) 

6) 

7) 

😎 

 

9) Now we are done for the moment. The next step is to continue in SAP Build Process Automation to finalize the automation.

 

If you want to test this use case by your own:

You need to activate the SAP Signavio Lab Space --> more details here on how to activate the Lab Space

And you need SAP Build Process Automation which is a BTP service and also available in a free tier model

Conclusion

What once required hours of manual modeling can now be achieved in minutes. By combining:

  • Text (or voice) descriptions

  • SAP Signavio’s Text to Process AI

  • Signavio Process Manager for refinement

  • SAP Build Process Automation for execution

…you can go from raw knowledge to documented process to automation in just a few steps.

This seamless integration enables business and IT to collaborate more effectively and accelerates the path from idea to execution.

So next time you describe a process in words remember, you’re only a few clicks away from automating it.

See you!

entry.title: SAP BTP for HR at SAP Connect and Success Connect 2025 summary - bigger and better than ever
entry.content:
Come see SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP) at this year’s SAP Connect / Success Connect event in Las Vegas! Due to the ever-increasing interest in SAP BTP topics and our sessions in prior years having standing-room only attendance, SAP BTP has more sessions than ever before! We even have for the first time ever, not one, but two hands-on-labs!

Related: For more information about SAP BTP presence outside of HCM, see these two articles:

  • Success Connect: Your People Deserve More Than Just Software - They Deserve Success - SAP Community
  • SAP Connect 2025: The Ultimate Business Transformation Experience - SAP Community

 

SAP BTP topics for 2025

This year’s SAP BTP for HR experience at SAP Connect is all about more. More business scenarios, more technology, more platform - more BTP! This year’s topics include customer favorites such as integration, extensibility and automation as well as numerous SAP SuccessFactors product-led sessions about how SAP BTP helps them deliver better solutions making it easier for customers to streamline HCM processes. Additionally, as we see an increase in technical audience members, we’ll be featuring slightly more
technical product deep dives by the product teams (also a first for us!).

Demos and hands-on labs

Demo-station demo: Automate new hire equipment ordering during onboarding, featuring Integration Suite Advanced Event Mesh

We’re showcasing two demos at the “Integration and Extension with SAP BTP” demo station. The first is our popular Automate new hire equipment ordering during onboarding demo which shows SAP Integration Suite’s Advanced Event Mesh event-driven integration capabilities to provide automated equipment ordering. This dramatically reduces the amount of time a people manager spends ordering equipment as well as requesting access to systems and data. If you missed this demo in Lisbon last year, then this is your chance!  Included are:

  • See how we used SAP Signavio Process Intelligence to analyze onboarding processes to identify key areas to address inefficiencies: hiring manager ordering of equipment, waiting for responses from people via email
  • SAP Integration Suite and advanced event mesh which offers real-time triggering of data synchronization based on SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central event triggers
  • An example app an IT department can create to offer pre-bundled packages of equipment to make it easier for managers to pick equipment, and to standardize offerings
  • One-click approvals by the hiring manager, powered by SAP Build 
  • Automatically submitting equipment selection to SAP Ariba guided buying via SAP Integration Suite
  • Notifications pushed to the task center for the hiring manager via SAP Build
  • Automatic submission of support tickets to SAP Service Cloud for manual tasks like requesting access to systems and data


Demo-station demo: Create a mobile app with SAP Build demo and hands-on lab

Additionally, we’re showing our brand new Create a mobile app with SAP Build demo which is specifically designed for more technical HRIS audiences in collaboration with the SAP SuccessFactors team. 

This demo is also the basis of two, 75-minute hands-on labs we’re offering this year which are sure to sell out! The lab will walk non-technical novices and intermediate technical knowledge people (non-developers, IT and HRIS are our target audience) on how to use SAP Build to quickly and easily create a mobile app with SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central people data to offer location-specific benefits for a field office – all with no coding, using SAP Build’s powerful drag-and-drop development interface. We’ll have product experts from the SAP Build team presenting and explaining to the audience the different capabilities of SAP Build in a follow-the-presenter format from their own workstations in live SAP Build environments so everyone will be able to walk away with direct product knowledge of what’s possible.
Included in the session:

  • Overview of the low-code SAP Build environment
  • Overview of various content types, controls, functions available
  • Adding content and configuring to the controls
  • Using an integration to SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central for people data
  • Accessing benefits information in the employee profile via API
  • Customizing the look and feel of the app
  • Testing the app and deployment

View the hands-on lab in the event catalog: Hands-on lab: Creating a custom mobile app for HR using SAP Build solutions (limited capacity) | HCM1677

There’s also quick overview videos of both these demos on the SAP.com/btp-for-HR page as well!

 

SAP BTP-led sessions

Integration sessions


Maximizing HCM process efficiency with integration through SAP BTP | HCM1665

Discover how SAP Business Technology Platform and SAP Integration Suite enable integrations for SAP SuccessFactors HCM, automating tasks and processes. Explore third-party integration use cases, such as recruiting, onboarding, and data collection, and strategies for connecting hybrid landscapes, including legacy on-premises and third-party systems as well as event-driven integrations.

How to use event-driven integration to collaborate in real time | HCM1682

Explore how SAP Integration Suite advanced event mesh can use business events from SAP SuccessFactors solutions such as SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central to push data to other internal or external systems in real-time. See firsthand how you can use this capability to trigger immediate actions, such as when an employee is hired or terminated.



Application development and extensibility sessions

Increasing employee efficiency with automation capabilities in SAP BTP | HCM1671

Explore automation capabilities in SAP Business Technology Platform (SAP BTP) that can streamline your HCM processes. From recruiting and onboarding to document management, SAP BTP can help you reduce errors in manual data entry and make your employees happier by reducing repetitive and mundane tasks through automation and workflows.

Using SAP Build to extend your SAP SuccessFactors solutions | HCM1463

Standardized business processes have come a long way, but every company still has a few things it does differently from everybody else. SAP Build solutions can help extend your human capital management solutions to address your specific business needs. See firsthand how to create low-code/no-code apps that boost end-user adoption and efficiency.

 

SAP SuccessFactors-led technology sessions including SAP BTP


These SAP SuccessFactors product expert-led sessions discuss how SAP BTP solutions help SAP SuccessFactors deliver better solutions to our customers as well as ways customers may not be aware of how they can use SAP BTP today with their existing SAP SuccessFactors solutions.

 

AI Technology, use cases and innovation

Road map and vision: AI in SAP SuccessFactors HCM | HCM1451

Look at SAP’s AI strategy and planned AI innovations in SAP SuccessFactors HCM. See what’s on the AI road map for HCM and get insights into SAP’s responsible, real-world AI approach. AI-driven capabilities such as the Joule copilot, AI agents, and the mobile experience with Joule  enhance employee experience, adaptability, and productivity

Unlocking and extending the Joule copilot with Joule Studio | HCM1571

Experience how Joule Studio allows you to create and deploy custom Joule agents and skills that improve efficiency across SAP and third-party systems and enhance your HR experience. Learn about prerequisites and how to get started, and find out how the agent builder capability in Joule Studio can empower you to create your own intelligent agents.

Everything you need to know about AI agents for HCM | HCM1468

AI agents are "smart teammates" that can observe, plan, and act, often without human intervention. Get a first look at some of the Joule Agents in the HCM road map, such as those for performance and goals, HR service, and people intelligence. Learn how agents can automate complex workflows, augment human capabilities, and drive efficiency.

 

 

Employee experience via integration and extensibility

Drive productivity by integrating and extending your HCM solutions | HCM1081

Discover how our recent innovations around integration and extension can help transform your business operations and enhance the user experience. You can use these technologies to integrate and extend your SAP SuccessFactors HCM portfolio with SAP Business Technology Platform.

Enhancing people profiles with SAP Business Technology Platform | HCM1520

See firsthand how you can enhance the latest people profile using SAP Business Technology Platform (SAP BTP), with an exclusive preview of advanced features slated for early adopter release in the second half of 2025. Learn how to extend people profiles to meet your organization’s needs and boost the user experience.

 

 

Technology and administration


Road map and vision: Application and technology foundation | HCM1030

Explore the latest innovations and enhancements in the technology and application foundation of SAP SuccessFactors solutions, including the SAP Business Data Cloud solution, Joule Studio, security, integration, extensibility through SAP Build solutions, and more. See demos and gain insights into what we have planned for our upcoming releases.

Simplifying your system administration to maximize business continuity | HCM1106

Explore innovative solutions to streamline system configuration and administration of your SAP SuccessFactors solutions. Gain practical tips on how your organization can modernize infrastructure management and boost efficiency with powerful administrative capabilities.

Fortifying together: Best practices for partner and customer security | HCM1061

Explore collaboration strategies and best practices for bolstering security across partners and customers. Discover how collective efforts and aligned practices can mitigate risks and build resilient ecosystems. Don't miss this opportunity to strengthen your security framework and foster trust among your business network.

 

If you haven’t attended Success Connect in the past (now SAP Connect), this year is the time to come to see all the great BTP content and sessions! Learn more about SAP Connect on the event page.

entry.title: Developing Processes in SAP Build Process Automation for Integrated Product Development
entry.content:
Introduction

SAP Build Process Automation (SBPA) is SAP’s new low-code/no-code platform that replaces Business Application Studio (BAS) for workflow development. With SBPA, workflows can be modeled, automated, and integrated visually, making it easier to connect business processes with collaboration scenarios.

In this article, we will walk through the complete journey: creating your first process in SBPA, deploying and running it in Integrated Product Development (IPD). You can follow the step-by-step instructions together with the screenshots to easily reproduce each step on your own system.

To get started, you need two prerequisites: a properly configured SBPA environment and an existing IPD Collaboration. Guidance for setting up Collaboration can be found in the official SAP Help for IPD Collaboration, while instructions for preparing SBPA are available in the SBPA Setup Guide.

 

Build your first Process

Step 1: Create a New Project

When you first log in to SAP Build Process Automation, you will see the Welcome to SAP Build page. Since there are no projects available yet, you need to start by creating a new one.

  1. Go to the All Projects section.
  2. Click on the Create button (highlighted in the top-right corner).

Step 2: Select the Project Type

In the Create Project wizard, you first need to define the objective of your project.

  1. Choose Automated Process (the middle option).
    • This option allows you to build process automations using drag-and-drop simplicity within SAP Build.
    • After selecting Automated Process, click Next to proceed.

Step 3: Choose the Development Type

After defining the objective, you now select the type of development configuration for your project.

  1. You will see two options:
    • Process – Build a business process to automate a workflow (e.g., sales order automation, invoice management, approval flows).
    • Automation – Automate repetitive tasks across applications (e.g., robotic process automation for manual tasks).
  2. For this tutorial, select Process.
    • This option enables you to design complete workflows with multiple steps, approvals, and integrations.
  3. Once selected, click Next to proceed to the project setup.

Step 4: Define the Project Name and Description

Next, you need to provide a meaningful name and description for your project. This will help you and your team easily identify the purpose of the process later.

  1. In the Name field, enter a clear and descriptive title for your project.
  2. In the Description field, provide additional details about the project’s purpose or scope.
  3. Once completed, click Review to proceed to the summary step.

Step 5: Review and Create the Project

The final step of the project creation wizard is to review your configuration before creating the project.

  1. The Summary page displays an overview of your selections:
    • Objective
    • Type
    • Name
    • Description
  2. Carefully check that all information is correct.
    • If needed, use the Edit links to make adjustments.
  3. Once everything looks good, click Create (bottom-right corner).

Your new project will now be generated, and you will be taken to the project workspace where you can start designing and automating your business process.

 

Step 6: Create a New Process

After creating the project, the next step is to define your first process inside it.

  1. In the Create Process dialog, provide the following details:
    • Name*: Enter a clear and descriptive process name.
    • Identifier*: Automatically filled
    • Description: Optionally, add a short description explaining the purpose of the process.
  2. Once all required fields are filled out, click Create.

Your process will be added to the project, and you can now begin designing the workflow by adding triggers, actions, and automation steps.

Step 7: Define a Process Trigger

Every process in SAP Build needs a trigger to define how it will start.

  1. Add a Trigger.
  2. In the Trigger configuration, you will see multiple options:
    • Submit a Form – The process starts when a user submits a predefined form.
    • API Trigger – The process is started by an external system or application through an API call.
    • Wait for an Event – The process begins when a specific event occurs.
    • Scheduled Trigger – The process runs automatically on a defined schedule.
  3. To use BPA with IPD, select API Trigger.
    • This option allows your process to be called programmatically by IPD.
  4. Select a name for your Trigger

 

Step 8: Configure Process Variables

To make your process dynamic, you need to define variables such as inputs, outputs, or custom fields. These variables allow data to flow through the process.

  1. Open the Process Details panel by clicking the side arrow button on the right hand side of the screen.
  2. Navigate to the Variables tab.
  3. Under Process Inputs, click Configure to define the data that your process should receive when triggered.
    • Process Inputs: Data passed into the process when it starts (e.g., order ID, customer name).
    • Process Outputs: Data that the process returns after execution.
    • Custom Variables: Additional internal variables you can use within the process flow.

 

Step 9: Define Process Inputs for BPA–IPD Connection

In order to establish the connection between BPA and IPD, you must configure the Process Inputs exactly as shown. These inputs are required for the API trigger to pass data correctly into the process.

  1. Open the Configure Process Inputs dialog.
  2. Add the following two inputs:

Important: If these inputs are not configured correctly, the API trigger will not be able to pass the required values, and the integration with IPD will fail.

  • Name: Subject
    • Identifier: subject
    • Description
    • Type: String
  • Name: Business Key
    • Identifier: businessKey
    • Description
    • Type: String
  • Make sure that both fields are created exactly with these Names and Identifiers.
    • The Identifier values (subject, businessKey) are case-sensitive and must match exactly to ensure proper data exchange with IPD.

Once everything is set, click Apply.

Step 10: Bind Process Inputs to the Process Details

After creating the required inputs (Subject and Business Key), you must bind them to the process definition so that they are recognized and used by BPA when triggered.

  1. Close and reopen the Process Details Panel.
  2. In the Process Content panel (on the left), expand Process Inputs.
    • You should see the variables Business Key and Subject listed.
  3. In the Process Details section (on the right):
    • Bind the Subject input variable, or
    • Enter a custom text string (e.g., IPD Process).
    • For the Subject field, you can either:
    • For the Business Key field, you must bind the Business Key input variable.

Important:

  • The Business Key is required. It uniquely identifies the process instance with a collaboration room.
  • The Subject is more flexible, it can either use the variable or a static text, depending on how you want the process name to appear in the work items tab of the collaboration room

 

Step 11: Add the First Step to the Process

Now that the trigger and process inputs are defined, you can begin building the workflow by adding steps between the trigger and the end node.

In the process flow, click the “+” symbol between the ProcessTrigger and the End node.

Step 12: Add a Form Step

When you add a step to your process, you can choose from different task types such as Approval, Automation, Email, or Decision.

  1. In the Choose what happens next dialog, select Form.
    • A Form step allows you to create a user-friendly form that can be filled out by process participants.
    • This is ideal for capturing data inputs (e.g., request details, feedback, approvals) at runtime.
  2. After selecting Form, you will be prompted to either:
    • Reuse an existing form already available in the project, or
    • Create a new blank form from scratch.

In this tutorial, we will continue by selecting Blank Form to design a new one.

Step 13: Configure the Form Step

Once the Form has been added to your process, you need to configure its general settings and assign key properties.

  1. In the Form step configuration panel (right side), define the following:
    1. Step Name: A descriptive name for the form step (e.g., MyTestForm).
  2. Set the required fields
    • Subject*:
    • Description: Optionally add a short explanation for the form’s purpose.
    • Priority*: Select the task priority (e.g., Low, Medium, High).
    • Users: Enter individual user mails, seperated by a comma.
    • Groups: Assign the task to a predefined user group.

Step 14: Open the Form Editor

After configuring the general settings for your form step, you can now design the form itself.

  1. In the Form Step Configuration panel, click Open Editor (next to the Form field).
    • This will open a new tab with the Form Designer where you can add and arrange input fields.

 

Step 15: Design the Form in the Form Editor

Once inside the Form Editor, you can create the layout and define the fields that the user will interact with during the process.

  1. Add and configure form elements:
    • Use the toolbar on the left (Text, Headings, Input fields, Checkboxes, Dropdowns, etc.) to drag components into the form area.
    • In this example, a Text Field labeled Test Data is added as a required field.
    • You can also include links, buttons, or additional sections for richer forms.
  2. Customize the form content:
    • Add a descriptive title or instructions (e.g., Please enter some test data).
    • Define placeholders, default values, and whether a field is mandatory.
  3. Save the form:
    • Once you’ve added and configured your fields, click Save in the top-right corner.

Saving ensures the form is available in your process and can be used in runtime execution.

Step 16: Save the Process

Once the process has been designed, you need to save and then release it to make it executable.

  1. Go back to the process
  2. Save the process
    • Click the Save button (top right corner).
    • This ensures all recent changes including triggers, forms, and variables are stored in the project.

The status will update to Saved.

Step 17: Define the Release Version and Notes

When you release the process, you need to provide versioning information and optionally describe the changes.

  1. In the Release Project dialog, enter the following details:
    • Use semantic versioning:
      • Major (X.0.0) for big new features or breaking changes.
      • Minor (0.X.0) for enhancements or smaller changes.
      • Patch (0.0.X) for bug fixes.
    • Release Version: Define the version number (e.g., 1.0.0).
    • Release Notes: Provide a short summary of the main changes in this version (e.g., Initial release with form input).

Click Release to finalize.

Step 18: Confirm and Deploy the Released Project Version

After releasing the project, SAP Build confirms that the process has been published successfully.

  1. A green confirmation message appears at the top of the screen:
    • Click Show project version to open details of the released version.
  2. In the Project Version Overview, you can review:
    • The artifacts (e.g., IPD Process, MyTestForm).
    • The triggers that start the process.
    • The dependencies, if any.
  3. To make the process executable in your environment, click Deploy (top-right corner).
    • Release makes a version available.

Deploy activates it so the process can actually be triggered (via UI or API).

Step 19: Confirm Deployment and Trigger Creation

When deploying a project version, SAP Build will inform you about the effect on triggers.

  1. In the Effect on Triggers dialog, you can see which triggers will be created or updated.
    • In this example: ProcessTrigger → Will be created.
  2. Click Deploy to confirm.
    • This activates the trigger and makes the process executable in your environment.

Once deployed, external systems (like IPD) can call this trigger via API to start the process.

Step 20: Verify the Deployment Status

After deployment, you can confirm that your process is active and ready to run.

  1. In the Project Overview, the status indicators will show:
    • Deployed → The process version has been successfully deployed.
    • Active → The process is currently live and can be triggered.

Step 21: Switch to IPD

Once your process is deployed and active in SAP Build Process Automation (SBPA), you can continue with the integration in IPD (Integrated Product Development).

Step 22: Open Workflow Properties in IPD

To connect your deployed BPA process with IPD, you first need to configure the workflow properties.

  1. In the Collaboration launchpad, locate the tile Workflow Properties.

Click on Workflow Properties to open the configuration settings

Step 23: Create a Workflow Property for the BPA Process in IPD

Workflow Properties in IPD allow you to define additional technical parameters for integrating and controlling your process.

  1. In the Workflow Properties overview, click Create.
  2. In the Create Workflow Property dialog:
    • Workflow*: Select your BPA workflow (e.g., IPD Process).
    • Workflow Property*: Enter a property name.
    • Property Value: Define the value to be used for this property.
    • Property Value Description: (Optional) Add a description to make the property easier to understand.
  3. Additional options:
    • Assign Users to Business Role: Links the property to specific business roles.
    • Default Property Value: Provides a fallback if no value is passed at runtime.
    • Allow Changes at Runtime: Enable this if the property should be overwritten during execution.
  4. Click Save to create the workflow property.

Step 24: Open Configure Collaboration in IPD

To finalize the integration and ensure that your BPA process can be executed within IPD, you need to configure collaboration settings.

  1. In the Collaboration launchpad, locate the Configure Collaboration tile.
  2. Click on Configure Collaboration.

Step 25: Define a New Collaboration Type in IPD

To connect your BPA process with a collaboration, you must create a new collaboration type.

  1. In the New Collaboration Type dialog, provide the following details:
    • ID*: A unique identifier for this collaboration type (e.g., BACT).
    • Description*: A descriptive name (e.g., Build Process Automation Collaboration Type).
    • Purpose: (Optional) Enter the business purpose of this collaboration type.
    • Status: Initially set to In Preparation.
  2. Under General Information:
    • Status Profile*: Select a profile that defines the process status lifecycle (e.g., Simple Statusnet (SIMPLE)).
    • Processing Status Profile: (Optional) Add if additional status handling is required.
    • Workflows*: Select your deployed workflow from BPA (e.g., IPD Process).
    • Reference Objects: (Optional) Add objects if you want to link the collaboration type to specific business entities.
    • Collaboration Header Fields: (Optional) Add header fields to store additional metadata.
  3. Under Configure Tabs:
    • Select the tabs that should be available for this collaboration type (e.g., Work Items, Shared Documents, Shared Product Data).
    • To add a workflow you must add the Work Items Tab.
  4. Click Save to create the collaboration type.

Step 26: Activate the Collaboration Type (Set to “In Use”)

After creating your new Collaboration Type, you must activate it so it can be used within IPD.

  1. In the Collaboration Types overview, locate the entry you just created (e.g., BACT – Build Process Automation Collaboration Type).
  2. Select the checkbox next to the ID.
  3. Click Set to “In Use” in the toolbar.
    • This changes the status from In Preparation to In Use.
    • Once active, the Collaboration Type can be used in collaboration scenarios and will connect with your process.

Step 27: Create a Collaboration

Once your Collaboration Type is set to In Use, you can create a new Collaboration with the Collaboration Type.

  1. Navigate to the My Collaborations in the Collaboration launchpad.
  2. Click Create.
  3. Enter the required details:
    • Collaboration Type: Select the Collaboration Type you activated earlier (e.g., BACT).
    • Collaboration Name: Provide a meaningful name (e.g., Build Process Automation Testing).
  4. Save the Collaboration.

From the My Collaborations Overview click on the arrow on the right to access a Collaboration.

Step 28: Add Workflow to the Collaboration

To connect your Collaboration instance with the BPA process, you must add the workflow that was deployed earlier.

  1. Open your Collaboration (e.g., Build Process Automation Testing).
  2. Navigate to the Work Items tab.
  3. At the bottom of the screen, click Add Workflow.

Step 29: Configure the Workflow in the Collaboration

When you add a workflow to a collaboration, you must configure its details.

  1. In the Add Workflow dialog:
    • Workflow*: Select the deployed workflow (e.g., IPD Process).
    • Title*: This is automatically filled. You can adjust if needed, but once saved, it cannot be changed.
  2. (Optional) Linked Files and Folders:
    • You can attach documents that will be shared with participants in this collaboration.
  3. (Optional) Linked Reference Object:
    • If required, assign reference objects that provide additional business context (e.g., product IDs, project numbers).
  4. (Optional) Comments:
    • Add notes or context for this workflow assignment.
  5. Click Add to link the workflow to the collaboration.

Step 30: Monitor the Workflow Execution

After adding the workflow to your collaboration, you can now start and observe the process execution.

  1. Go to the Work Items tab of your Collaboration (you may have to refresh).
  2. You will see an entry for the workflow you just added (e.g., IPD Process).
    • Running → The workflow is active.
    • Ready → A form or task is waiting for user action.
    • Completed → The workflow or step is finished.
    • The Title column shows the subject defined earlier (e.g., This is my test form).
    • The Status column indicates the current execution state:

Step 31: Open “My Inbox” from the Collaboration Launchpad

To act on user tasks created by your BPA workflow (e.g., the Form step), use the My Inbox app.

  1. In the Collaboration launchpad, open My Inbox.

Step 32: Complete the Form Task in My Inbox

This is the user task created by your BPA workflow. Fill it in and submit to advance the process.

  1. Enter the required data:
    • In the field Test Data (marked with an asterisk), type a value. Required fields must be filled before submission.
    • Optional: follow any informational links shown in the form (e.g., Link to sap.com).
  2. Submit the task:
    • Click Submit to send the form back to the workflow.
    • If validation errors appear, correct them and submit again.

Step 33: Verify Workflow Completion in the Collaboration

Confirm that your end-to-end flow finished successfully.

  1. In the Collaboration view, open your Collaboration
  2. Open the Work Items tab.
  3. Check the rows for your workflow (e.g., IPD Process) and its task (e.g., This is my test form).
    • Status should be Completed.
    • Assignee/Processor, Created On, and Completed On show who finished it and when.

Conclusion

Good job! You created your first process in SAP Build Process Automation (SBPA) and successfully deployed it in Integrated Product Development (IPD). With this foundation in place, you now have a running workflow that you can trigger, monitor, and extend.

The next step is to take your automation even further by integrating APIs from the SAP Business Accelerator Hub. This will allow you to enrich your workflows with collaboration features, business data, and advanced automation scenarios. Stay tuned for my next blog post, where I will guide you through adding APIs to your SBPA processes step by step.

Alexandra Rong,
Business Process Consultant for SAP IPD,
alexandra.rong@sap.com

entry.title: Extending SBPA Processes with APIs and Using Them in Integrated Product Development
entry.content:
Introduction

In the first blog post, we built and deployed a functional workflow in SAP Build Process Automation (SBPA) and connected it to Integrated Product Development (IPD). Now, it’s time to take the next step: extending your process with API integrations.

In this article, we will explore how to set up and use APIs within SBPA processes to enrich your workflows with collaboration data and advanced functionality from IPD. You will learn how to:

  • Add and configure destinations
  • Set up and manage Actions in SBPA
  • Include and execute API calls directly within your process

Our specific goal in this post is to retrieve the Collaboration Name via an API call and make it visible inside a form within your workflow. By the end of this post, you’ll know how to connect SBPA to IPD Collaboration APIs and enrich your workflow with live collaboration data.

Prerequisite: You need a functional IPD workflow in SBPA. If you haven’t created one yet, you can follow my step-by-step guide to build a process in SBPA and integrate it into IPD.

 

Guide

Step 1: Register the EDP_Collaboration destination in SBPA

  1. From the SAP Build (SBPA) Lobby, open Control Tower.
  2. Under Backend Configuration, click Destinations.

Step 2: Select the EPD_Collaboration destination

  1. To add a destination, click the Add button.
  2. Choose the EPD_Collaboration destination from the list.
  3. Click Next to proceed to Associate Environments.

Step 3: Associate the destination with environments

  1. In the Associate Environments step, choose how the destination should be available:
    • All Environments: makes the destination usable in every SBPA environment.
    • Specific Environments: select only the environments where this destination should be active.
  2. Click Add Destination to save.

Step 4: Create an Actions project

  1. In the SBPA Lobby, go to Connectors → Actions.
  2. Click Create (top-right).

Step 5: Import the IPD Collaboration API from the SAP Business Accelerator Hub

  1. In your Actions project, click Choose an API Source and select SAP Business Accelerator Hub.
  2. In the search bar, type Collaboration and select Collaboration (ODATA) under SAP Integrated Product Development (IPD).
  3. Import the API into your Actions project.

Step 6: Create the Action Project

  1. After selecting the Collaboration API, you will be prompted to create an Action project.
  2. The Project Name and Description are prefilled with default values. You can keep them or adjust as needed.
  3. Click Create to finalize the Action project setup.

Step 7: Add Available API Actions

  1. A list of API actions from the SAP Business Accelerator Hub will appear.
  2. Select the APIs you want to use for your collaboration scenario (for this guide: Retrieve a collaboration for the specified collaboration ID).
  3. Confirm with Add.
  4. All chosen API actions will now be available in your Action Project.

Tip: If you want to add an API later, open the Available Actions window using the Add button next to Actions.

Step 8: Add missing "From" header for IPD APIs

For many IPD APIs, an additional From header is required. This header is not automatically included and must be configured manually.

  1. Open Add under the Parameters section.
  2. Configure the parameter as follows:
    • Key: From
    • Mandatory: Yes
    • Parameter: header
    • Type: string
  3. Add the parameter.

To check whether an API requires the From header, refer to the SAP API Business Hub – EPD Collaboration API.

Step 9: Save, Release and Publish the Action Project

  1. Click Save.
  2. Click Release.
  3. Click Publish.

Step 10: Move back into the process

After releasing and publishing the Action Project, return to your process model to continue the setup.

  1. Open your project in SAP Build Process Automation.
  2. Switch the project from Deployed back to Editable mode by selecting the dropdown and choosing Editable.
    • This allows you to make changes to the process again.
  3. In the project overview, click on your process (e.g., IPD Process) to reopen it in the process editor.

Step 11: Add the CollaborationID and TechnicalUser as custom variables

  1. Under Process Details, configure Custom Variables.
  2. Add CollaborationID and technicalUser as custom variables.
    • You can either set the technicalUser directly as an initial variable or define it later in a Script Task.

Step 12: Extract the Collaboration ID from the Business Key

  1. Add a Script Task to your process.
  2. In the script editor, insert the following JavaScript logic:
// get Business Key
var businessKey = $.context.startEvent.businessKey;

// delete "Collaboration"
var collaborationId = businessKey.replace("Collaboration", "");

// Write in Context
$.context.custom.collaborationid = collaborationId;
$.context.custom.technicalUser = "your@mail.com"; // enter the technical User Mail

Step 13: Add Collaboration Actions

  1. After the Script Task, add a new element and select Action.
  2. This connects the Collaboration API (configured earlier) directly to your process.
  3. You can either reuse an existing action from your library or add a new one by selecting Browse All Actions.
  4. In the Action Library, search for and select the Collaboration API you want to use (In this guide the API: Retrieves a collaboration for the specified collaboration ID).

Step 14: Configure Destination Variable

  1. Choose a Name for the step.
  2. Under Destination Variable, create or select the variable that points to your Collaboration destination.
  3. When deploying the workflow, set this destination variable to EPD_Collaboration.

Step 15: Configure API Inputs

  1. In the workflow action settings, navigate to the Inputs tab.
  2. For the field From, select the variable technicalUser.
  3. For the field ID, select the variable CollaborationID.

This maps your process data to the API request. All responses from the API call are available as variables, which can be mapped and used in the input fields.

Step 16: Add result from API to your Form

  1. Open the form.
  2. Click Open Editor.
  3. Add a Text Field and name it Collaboration Name.
  4. Save the form.
  5. Return to the Process and open the Input tab of the form.
  6. Add the Collaboration Name into the field.

Step 17: Save, Release, and Deploy the Project

  1. Save your project after adding the API steps.
  2. Release the project to make it ready for deployment.
  3. During deployment, set the Destination Variable to the EPD_Collaboration destination.

Step 18: Start the Workflow in SAP IPD

  1. Open the My Collaborations app in SAP IPD.
  2. Select a collaboration where the workflow is already linked to the collaboration type (see how to do that: SBPA Guide)
  3. Add the workflow to the collaboration.

Note: This requires that you have completed all configuration steps from the SBPA guide, including setting up the Business Key, defining the Subject, and configuring the Workflow Properties and other prerequisites. Since the process was already configured, deploying it in SBPA only creates a new version of the workflow. When you start the workflow in IPD, the newly deployed version will be executed. 

Step 20: Check the updated form in My Inbox

  1. Open the My Inbox app in SAP IPD.
  2. Select the task created by your workflow.
  3. In the form, locate the text field Collaboration Name.
  4. The field now displays the Collaboration Name that was returned by the API.

Optional: Monitor the Workflow

  1. Use the Monitor Workflow app to track execution details.
  2. In the monitoring view, verify that the API call is executed successfully and inspect the request and response data if needed.

Conclusion

Great work! You have successfully extended your workflow in SAP Build Process Automation by integrating APIs and connected it with Integrated Product Development. With the Collaboration API in place, your process can now dynamically retrieve and display collaboration data, such as the Collaboration Name, directly inside your forms.

Beyond this example, you can use many other APIs from the SAP Business Accelerator Hub to enrich your workflows with additional business data, collaboration features, or system integrations. This demonstrates how SBPA can go beyond simple workflow automation and become a powerful integration layer for IPD.

Alexandra Rong,
Business Process Consultant for SAP IPD,
alexandra.rong@sap.com

entry.title: Kickstart Your SAP BTP Journey
entry.content:
All you need to know and where to start

You may have come across articles, presentations, interviews or discussions about SAP Business Technology Platform (SAP BTP). You heard the term quite often, but you might still be asking:  

  • What exactly is SAP BTP?
  • Why is SAP BTP important?
  • And how do I begin exploring SAP BTP’s potential?
  • How does SAP BTP fit into the clean core strategy?

You’re now at the right place.

Whether you're a decision maker looking to drive IT strategy, an IT professional building solutions, a business user focused on innovation, or part of the academic community exploring cutting-edge technologies, this post is your launchpad into the world of SAP BTP.

Curious where you fit in? Keep reading to discover the tools, learning paths, and support SAP BTP offers for every IT role: from developers and architects to students, educators, and decision makers.

No matter your background or goals, there’s a starting point tailored just for you.

 

What We’ll Cover Here

  1. What Is SAP BTP?
  2. Why SAP BTP Matters
  3. SAP BTP and clean core
  4. Try Before You Buy: Trials & Pricing Models
  5. Real Talk: What Are Others Doing with SAP BTP?
  6. SAP BTP Essentials: Resources for Every IT Role
  7. Stay Ahead: Strategy, Roadmaps & Updates
  8. Start building today!

 

What is SAP BTP?

SAP BTP is an intuitive, modern development and innovation platform for both professional IT and business users. It is a unified platform that brings quickly together everything you need to build any idea or business vision to life, extending, and integrating existing business applications, whether they’re SAP or not.

With self-service data discovery, modeling, planning, and analytics for business users in a governed environment, it provides integration solutions to connect and streamline applications and processes across the entire enterprise, offering pre-built business content like built-in data products, integrations, workflows, app templates, and AI services.

Here’s what’s in the toolbox:

  • App Development & Automation: Rapidly develop applications or automate processes using low-code/no-code tools or opt for professional-code development when advanced customization and control are required
  • Data & Analytics: Turn your data into decisions with built-in analytics and planning tools.
  • Integration: Connect SAP or non-SAP systems like a pro.
  • Artificial Intelligence: Infuse AI into your workflows, apps, and decisions.
  • Platform Foundation: Secure, scalable, and ready for hybrid cloud environments.

Simply put, SAP BTP enables you to innovate and stay relevant by building on established foundations.

 

Why SAP BTP Matters?

Because digital transformation is not just a trend, it’s essential for adaptability and resilience, a.k.a. survival.

With SAP BTP, you can:

  • Automate repetitive tasks and free up time for real work.
  • Connect all of your systems, so they integrate.
  • Build custom apps tailored to your business needs and vision.
  • Use AI to make smarter decisions, faster.
  • Connect and harmonize all your data, eliminating data silos
  • Get mission-critical insights from your data without a background in data science

And the best part? You don’t have to start from scratch.
SAP BTP offers thousands of pre-built content packages, from application or automation templates to integration flows to dashboards to AI services.

 

SAP BTP and clean core

Clean core is a set of guiding principles that support continuous business transformation by designing agile, innovative and efficient ERP systems. The principles focus on building resilient business processes and extensions supported by seamless integration, efficient operations, and data quality.

Central to the clean core strategy are Side-by-side extensions, powered by SAP BTP.

Side-by-side extensions allow organizations to enhance their SAP landscapes without directly modifying the core SAP S/4HANA system: instead of embedding custom code within the core, new functionalities, integrations, and custom applications are developed and deployed independently on SAP BTP.

This approach leverages SAP BTP's robust services, including various runtime environments (like Cloud Foundry, Kyma, and the ABAP Environment), development tools (like SAP Business Application Studio and CAP), and critical integration services (like SAP Integration Suite and SAP Event Mesh). Connectivity is securely handled by tools like the SAP Cloud Connector for on-premise systems and the Destination Service, ensuring seamless data exchange via standard APIs and business events from the core.

 

Try Before You Buy: Free Trials & Flexible Pricing Models
Not ready to commit? No problem

SAP BTP offers a 90-day free trial with access to 30+ services.

You can explore, experiment, and learn at your own pace how to build, deploy, and integrate with a full suite of platform services.

Start here your free trial of SAP Business Technology Platform.

When you're ready to scale, you’ve got options:

  • Free Tier: Build small apps, pay only for what you use.
  • Pay-As-You-Go: Great for dynamic needs and innovation projects.
  • Enterprise Agreement: Predictable pricing for known use cases.

Explore all the possibilities SAP BTP unlocks. We’ve outlined the opportunities below:

 

Real Talk: What Are Others Doing with SAP BTP?

Thousands of organizations, from global enterprises to emerging startups, are already leveraging SAP BTP to transform their operations. Let their success inspire you.
They are using SAP BTP to:

  • Automate supply chains
  • Personalize customer experiences
  • Streamline HR processes
  • Build AI-powered finance tools ... and achieve much more.

With over 33,000 customers and 3,200 partners, you'll be in excellent company.

See how SAP BTP customers are achieving a measurable impact across industries and lines of business.

 

SAP BTP Essentials: Resources for Every IT Role

Here’s your go-to list of resources to get rolling, matched to your role:

Note: This table is a starting point. Resource-role mappings are suggestions. Feel free to explore beyond your role based on your needs and interests. Find below what each of the resources has to offer.

SAP Discovery Center - Learn about SAP BTP Services in detail:

  • Start your experience with Guided Missions to bring real life use-cases to life
  • Reference established architectures patterns to guide your design and implementation
  • Understand how SAP BTP’s AI capabilities are used to infuse AI features into SAP’s solution portfolio
  • Create an estimate of your services to get a first impression about the usage cost.

SAP BTP Learning - Free learning journeys tailored to your role and pace:

  • Familiarize yourself with the basic concepts of SAP BTP.
  • Get enabled.
  • Plan your implementation.
  • Prepare for your go-live.

SAP BTP Guidance Framework - Provides a central access point for architects, developers, and administrators to build and run enterprise-grade solutions on SAP BTP:

  • Decision Guides: Quickly identify the best technology options for your specific needs.
  • Reference Architectures: Explore solution templates to effectively design and build on BTP, understanding key concepts and capabilities.
  • Methodologies: Access guided approaches to boost your cloud technology maturity, spanning both technical and organizational aspects.
  • Technology Recommendations: Evaluate and choose the right implementation options across various technology domains.
  • DevOps Principles: Empower your development and operations teams to achieve greater efficiency.

SAP Business Accelerator Hub  - Kickstart your projects with ready-to-use Business Content available for SAP BTP:

  • Integration: Access over 4,000 pre-built objects, including integration flows, scripts, value mappings, and message mappings, to streamline your connections with SAP Integration Suite
  • Development & Automation: Accelerate your projects with approximately 650 pre-built workflows, automations, applications, templates, and actions ready for use with SAP Build
  • Analytics: Jump-start your data insights using pre-built dashboards, stories, and data models specifically designed for SAP BTP's analytics capabilities
  • Information: Explore a rich repository of resources, including APIs, events, CDS views, business objects, interfaces, adapters, process blueprints, and SAP-validated partner use cases.

SAP Community - Connect with fellow SAP BTP users, ask questions and share ideas, get help and help others.

 

Stay Ahead: Strategy, Roadmaps & Updates

SAP Release Navigator - Keep up with the latest innovations and updates across SAP BTP, track new features and plan your adoption.

Road Map Explorer - Discover SAP’s product strategies and planned innovations with this go-to interactive tool. It highlights key advancements and offers a robust planning horizon, helping you precisely detail your transformation journey.

Strategy White Paper for SAP BTP - When you are ready to get deeper, discover more with SAP’s strategy for SAP BTP.

 

Start Building today!

Start your journey today with the SAP BTP Trial or explore your first mission at the SAP Discovery Center.

entry.title: Building Low-code/No-code SAP CPQ extension using SAP Build Process Automation (Part 1)
entry.content:
Introduction

SAP CPQ (Configure Price Quote) is a software solution that allows customers to configure products and services, set up pricing and discounts, generate accurate quotes, and create custom proposals. While offering a great deal of functionality out-of-the-box, SAP CPQ can also be easily extended and customized, to support custom, and often unique, business processes and procedures.

One way in which SAP CPQ can be extended is by developing an external extension application that is integrated with SAP CPQ using standard integration mechanisms (REST APIs, events, webhook notifications etc.). This approach, also known as side-by-side extensibility, has several distinctive benefits: increased flexibility in terms of technological choice, possibility of using dedicated resources, better performance due to limited scope and many more.

This series of blog posts will explore several ways for building and deploying side-by-side extensions of SAP CPQ, using the SAP BTP (Business Technology Platform) and various tools offered by that platform. In this first of the blog posts, we will see how we can use SAP Build Process Automation for building an extension that can be invoked from SAP CPQ by calling its dedicated API endpoint.

 

Overview of the solution

SAP Build Process Automation is a low-code/no-code solution that enables you to automate workflow processes without writing a single line of code, just by using a graphical, drag-and-drop editor. It is an ideal solution for developing both simple extensions, as well as complex business process applications. To learn more about SAP Build Process Automation, please check the official documentation.

Overview of the solution (including Part 1 and Part 2)

This blog post will demonstrate how to start an SAP Build Process Automation process from SAP CPQ global script using the concept of API Triggers. API Trigger represents an HTTP endpoint that can be invoked using the standard mechanism, and that will cause the new process instance to be started. API Triggers also allow you to , via the body of the HTTP request, specify the inputs that will be used for starting the process instance.

By the end of this blog post, I hope that I will be able to demonstrate how easy it is to start SAP Build Process Automation processes from SAP CPQ, and how this can be useful for extending the basic SAP CPQ functionality.

As an example extension application that we want to integrate with SAP CPQ, we are going to use a simple business process involving legal check of created quotes. The process triggers manual check based on the market associated with the quote, and allows the responsible persons to decide whether quote should be accepted or rejected from the legal perspective. The decision then triggers invocation of appropriate custom CPQ action, something that is described in the Part 2 of this series.

Example SAP Build Process Automation process used in this blog post series

Please note that, in this blog post, I assume that you are familiar with the basics of using SAP Build Process Automation. If that is not the case, please check the excellent "Creating Processes and Automations with SAP Build Process Automation" learning journey at SAP Learning.

 

Defining an API trigger for your SAP Build Process Automation process

To define a new API Trigger for your SAP Build Process Automation process, navigate to the process overview screen and select Add a Trigger.

Then, select the API Trigger.

Next, specify a descriptive name and identifier for this new API Trigger, and click on Create button.

You will see a newly defined API trigger as the first step in your SAP Build Process Automation process. To define inputs for your SAP Build Process Automation process (and, consequently, parameters for the API Trigger), click on the << to show the Process Details pane.

Here, click on Variables, and then on Configure button related to Process Inputs. Please note that if, prior to adding an API Trigger, you have already defined the rest of your process, Process Inputs will be automatically populated, which significantly simplifies the configuration. Still, even in that case, you can double-check the generated Process Inputs and make changes if necessary.

This will display the Configure Process Inputs popup, where you can define all the process inputs. To add a new input, click on the Add Input button, and specify the following:

  • Descriptive Name of the input parameter
  • Unique Identifier of the input parameter (unique for the concrete process you are configuring). This identifier will be used later, when we define a JSON object that will be sent as a request body when making a HTTP call to your SAP Build Process Automation process.
  • Optional Description of the input parameter
  • Type of the input parameter
  • Whether input parameter is Required or represents a List of values

After defining all the input parameters for the process, click on the Apply to make the changes.

You can consume these process input parameters in the same way as you would consume output of any other process step in the project: you can display them on the form, use them as input parameters for another action etc.  In our example, an action step is the first step of the process, so we can use process input parameters as the values of the input fields of the action by selecting them in the Process Content pane (under the Process Inputs section). These fields will have the corresponding types, according to the way you have configured them in the previous step.

 

Deploying SAP Build Process Automation project

Before being able to invoke your SAP Build Process Automation process via an HTTP call, you need to deploy your SAP Build Process Automation project in a desired environment (before doing that, please make sure that you have released a version of your project, as described in documentation).

The process of deploying SAP Build Process Automation project is described in detail in official documentation. When deploying the project, you will be notified about the creation of new triggers; just confirm by clicking on Deploy button.

 

Getting the instance endpoint and authentication data

To connect SAP CPQ with SAP Build Process Automation, it is necessary to get the endpoint and authentication data for your SAP Build Process Automation instance from the SAP BTP subaccount where that instance is located. To do so, go to the subaccount in BTP Cockpit, select Services -> Instances and Subscriptions, and then navigate the SAP Build Process Automation instance and click on > to display the instance details. (In case you currently don't have an instance of SAP Build Process Automation service available, you can create one by clicking the blue Create button in the top left corner of the screen and following the instructions)

Next, service key needs to be created, if there is none already available. Click on the Create button in the Service Keys section, enter the descriptive Service Key Name and click Create again.

Once service key is created, click on … button to show the menu, and then select View to display the endpoint and credentials information.

From the popup window displaying the credentials:

  • Note the uaa.clientid and uaa.clientsecret, representing the OAuth 2.0 client credentials used for obtaining access token that needs to be provided when accessing the API of your SAP Build Process Automation instance
  • Note the uaa.url, representing the base URL of the OAuth 2.0 authorization server used for obtaining access token that needs to be provided when accessing the API of your SAP Build Process Automation instance

After obtaining information from the service key, new Credential Management entry in the SAP CPQ needs to be created. In the SAP CPQ setup, go to Security -> Credential Management and click on New Entry:

  • Specify a descriptive Name for this entry, and make sure to note it down, because it will be used in later steps
  • Select Credential as an entry Type
  • For the Identifier field, use the value of uaa.clientid field obtained in the previous step
  • For the Secret field, use the value of uaa.clientsecret field obtained in the previous step

Once done, click Save.

Make sure to activate the newly created entry by clicking on the Active slider button.

After activating, slider should be positioned on the right.

 

Calling SAP Build Process Automation process from SAP CPQ global script

Two more pieces of information are needed before you will be able to call SAP Build Process Automation process from SAP CPQ: URL of the SAP Build Process Automation API endpoint and the unique identifier of your process. To find these, navigate your SAP Build Process Automation instance and select SAP Build Lobby -> Control Tower -> Environments. Then, select the environments where you have deployed your process.

Then, select Triggers and click on … button associated with the API Trigger you have created for your process. Select View option, and the popup window will be displayed.

From this window, note the URL value, as well as the value of the definitionId field of the JSON found in the Payload textbox.

Now we have all the needed information to implement a call to your process in an SAP CPQ global script. If you are not familiar with the concept of global scripts, they are a piece of custom code (written in IronPython) that can be attached to all kinds of events in SAP CPQ. Once the event has occurred, the global script is automatically executed. For more information about global scripts, please check the official documentation.

Invoking an SAP Build Process Automation process from global script requires two things: fetching an access token and making an HTTP call that will start the process itself. Fetching an access token can be done in the following way (here, we have extracted it into a separate method):

def fetch_access_token():
    credentials_store_entry = '<CREDENTIAL_MANAGEMENT_ENTRY_NAME>'
    token_endpoint = '<BUILD_PROCESS_AUTOMATION_INSTANCE_AS_URL>/oauth/token'
    response = AuthorizedRestClient.GetClientCredentialsGrantOAuthToken(credentials_store_entry, token_endpoint)
    return response['access_token']

You need to substitute:

  • <CREDENTIAL_MANAGEMENT_ENTRY_NAME> with the Name of the Credential Management entry you have created in SAP CPQ in the previous step
  • <BUILD_PROCESS_AUTOMATION_INSTANCE_AS_URL> with the value of the uaa.url field extracted from the service key in one of the previous steps (please note that the final token_endpoint is a concatenation of this value and '/oauth/token')

Now, to invoke an SAP Build Process Automation process, you can use the following snippet (of course, modified for your concrete business need):

url = '<BUILD_PROCESS_AUTOMATION_INSTANCE_ENDPOINT_API_URL>'
data = {
  "definitionId": "<BUILD_PROCESS_AUTOMATION_PROCESS_ID>",
  "context": <BUILD_PROCESS_AUTOMATION_PROCESS_INPUT_AS_JSON>
}
headers = { 'Authorization': 'Bearer {}'.format(fetch_access_token()) }
response = RestClient.Post(url, data, headers)
# handle the response (check for errors, etc.)

You need to substitute:

  • <BUILD_PROCESS_AUTOMATION_INSTANCE_ENDPOINT_API_URL> with the value of the URL you have just extracted from the popup window in the Triggers section
  • <BUILD_PROCESS_AUTOMATION_PROCESS_ID> with the value of the definitionId field you have just extracted from the popup window in the Triggers section
  • <BUILD_PROCESS_AUTOMATION_PROCESS_INPUT_AS_JSON> with a JSON object that matches the process inputs you have configured in one of the previous steps (with the Identifier of the input parameter representing name in the name-value pair)

For example, let's say that we have configured the following process inputs:

Then, our call would look like this:

url = '<BUILD_PROCESS_AUTOMATION_INSTANCE_ENDPOINT_API_URL>'
data = {
  "definitionId": "<BUILD_PROCESS_AUTOMATION_PROCESS_ID>",
  "context": {
    "quoteID": 12345 # or, for example context.Quote.Id
  }
}
headers = { 'Authorization': 'Bearer {}'.format(fetch_access_token()) }
response = RestClient.Post(url, data, headers)
# handle the response (check for errors, etc.)

(For more information, please consult the official documentation and API specification.)

That's it!

Conclusion

SAP Build Process Automation is a low-code/no-code solution that can be used for the development of side-by-side extensions of SAP CPQ. Side-by-side extensions can help you in customizing SAP CPQ to support your concrete business processes and requirements. In this blog post, we have demonstrated the way these extensions can be invoked from SAP CPQ. In the next post in the series, we will show you how SAP Build Process Automation processes can invoke SAP CPQ API in a secure and reliable way.

Resources

  • "Creating Processes and Automations with SAP Build Process Automation" learning journey at SAP Learning
  • API specification

entry.title: 5 Things You Didn’t Know About SAP Joule for Developers — Plus an Exciting Update
entry.content:
Artificial intelligence is reshaping how we work, and developers are among the first to feel the impact. SAP Joule for Developers is a collection of AI capabilities in SAP Build and ABAP Environment designed to help developers build smarter, faster, and more intuitively — whether you’re streamlining repetitive coding tasks or creating complex integrations. 

And here’s the big news: 
👉The free promotion for SAP Joule for Developers has been extended. 

That means you now have even more time to explore Joule, experiment with projects, and see firsthand how it can transform your workflows — all at no cost. 

We are hosting an engaging webinar with demos, use cases and best practices on how to maximize value with Joule in SAP Build. Read till the end to find the registration link!

Without further ado, here are five things you might not know about SAP Joule for Developers. 

 

1. It’s More Than Just an AI Assistant 

Many developers see Joule as just a chatbot. But it’s far more powerful. Joule for Developers goes beyond simple answers — it integrates into your workflow, generates context-aware code suggestions, and automates repetitive tasks. Whether you’re building in SAP Build, working in ABAP, or connecting with third-party services, Joule is designed to keep your productivity high. 

👉Learn more about capabilities via our webpage 

 

2. It Speaks “Developer” Fluently 

Joule understands technical prompts and adapts its recommendations to your specific context. Describe what you want to create, and Joule can generate API calls, reusable code snippets, or even integration patterns tailored to your environment. 

👉Explore a tutorial in ABAP here. 

 

3. Built-In Security and Compliance Awareness 

SAP Build—with SAP Joule for Developers embedded—is built on enterprise-grade security. It adheres to SAP’s compliance standards, so your code and data are always protected. You can confidently experiment with AI in your workflows, backed by privacy, governance, and regulatory safeguards. 

👉Read more about SAP’s approach to security and compliance in SAP Build and SAP Business Technology Platform. 

 

4. It Helps You Learn as You Build 

Joule isn’t just about solutions — it’s about learning. As you code, Joule explains the why behind its suggestions. This helps developers discover new frameworks, understand best practices, and ramp up on unfamiliar technologies faster. 

Think of it as a mentor who’s always available, providing guidance while letting you stay in the driver’s seat. 

👉Try a tutorial on how to create CAP application in SAP Build. 

 

5. It Works Across Your Development Stack 

Joule isn’t limited to a single tool or environment. Whether you’re generating processes or building applications, SAP Joule for Developers can support you. This flexibility means you can bring AI assistance into the environments you already know — without having to change how you work. 

 

Free Access to SAP Joule for Developers 

Now is the best time to explore, innovate, and see how Joule can transform the way you build — without worrying about cost. 

👉Get started today.  

📅Mark your calendar: Join our upcoming SAP Build with Joule webinar on September 24th to see live demos, best practices, and how to maximize the value of Joule in your projects. Register here.

entry.title: Using Document AI Premium in SAP Build Process Automation
entry.content:
Intro

SAP Document AI, previously known as Document Information Extraction or DOX, has been bundled in SAP Build Process Automation (SBPA) for many years. The bundled document extraction capabilities in SBPA are leveraging Document AI Base edition based on Machine Learning. Since the introduction of the LLM-based Document AI Premium, there are many cases where the Premium version is the best and prefered option, or you may want to combine both versions. Although SAP Document AI Premium can be connected to SBPA via API like any other BTP service, this still poses a challenge for many SBPA users, who expect a no-code activity similar to the bundled version (DOX SDK).
In this blog post, I will explain how to quickly leverage Document AI Premium in your process automation projects using a reusable package that we deploy in our proof-of-concept activities.

Prerequisites

The assumption is that you have a Document AI Premium service and destination configured on your SBPA subaccount. If not, please check the quick setup tips below and find detailed instructions in SAP Help:

  • Document AI Premium service: You should setup Document AI Premium in your BTP environment (can be on any subbacount). For CloudFoundry, easiest way is to use booster.
  • Destination: You should create a destionation, with all required additonal properties for SBPA, in the subbacount where you SAP Build Process Automation is activated and add it to your Build tenant. Easiest way to create a destionation is to download this example and import into your BTP cockpit. You should update 4 parameters (Client ID, Client Secret, Token Service URL and URL) with values from your Document AI Service key.  

Easiest way to start

I will first cover the simplest way to get started with Document AI Premium in your automation process, which will work for most users. The goal is to quickly enable the capability to add an activity that will synchronously call your Document AI Premium. 

You need to download the latest version of the reusable DocAI Premium package from this link (download the latest version of MTAR file called "(package) Document AI service") and import it into your SAP Build Lobby:

Once the reusable package is uploaded, go to "versions" and select "Publish to Library". Once published, the package will be available to all developers on this tenant.

Open or create an automation project and add this package as a dependency (very similar to the way you add standard SBPA SDK packages):

 

Now you have the reusable automation 'DocAI - Extract with Schema' in your project, which you can simply drag and drop into your automation flow. You can ignore the other automations for now, as they are meant for advanced cases that I will cover separately. For most users, they are not relevant.

There are 2 input parameters: "fileToUpload" and "schemaName".

"File to upload" is self-explanatory; just provide a local path to a document that you want to process with the Document AI Premium service. "Schema name" refers to any SAP standard or custom schema that is created in your Document AI Premium. Make sure to use the exact name of any standard or custom schema.

And that's it. Once you run your autmation, there will be 3 output parameters that you can use:

  • fullResponse: Exact full output from the Document AI service (e.g., confidence level, page, coordinates, etc.)
  • extractedData:Simplified response with only the header and line items fields of your schema. This output is useful if you just want to map extracted data to your Action call, any API or BAPI call, or quickly map exact schema key values.
  • Status: Status of the extracted document. This field is here for simplification. The status is anyway returned in the fullResponse.status where you can also find additional details if there is a failure. For example, the document may have a valid extension but is corrupted, which will result in a "FAILED" status. To handle this, you can add IF logic after extraction and simply check if the Status == "FAILED" and then take appropriate action.

You can see the difference between the two output responses in the example below:

Notes for advanced automation users

You can double-click on the automation "DocAI - Extract with Schema" and see how this automation works. You will notice that it's uploading the document and waiting for the Document AI Premium service response. You can use the upload automation to send a document to the service, and then start a process that will wait for the service response and continue with the process flow. This asynchronous approach will help you process many more documents with one unattended connection compared to the typical synchronous automation. I will cover this in a separate post, but here is the concept:

You can also activate or deactivate the Instant Learning capability of your Document AI Premium with the automations provided in the package. There is no need to deploy anything. Just add the automations to an empty project and run them in test mode.

For those of you who are familiar with reusable packages (Library) and understand the implications of deploying a new version of your own, here is the editable version of this package so you can adjust it for your specific needs. I don’t advise doing that if you are not familiar with Library concepts and all implications of import and export activities.

Conclusion

I hope this package will speed up and simplify your automation projects with Document AI Premium. Package supports both Windows and Mac OS desktop agents. Let me know how it works for you in the comments below. 

I plan to cover the following topics in upcoming posts:

  • Example automation projects that are leveraging this package
  • Asynchronous approach for faster processing of large volumes of documents
  • How to combine new Document AI Workspaces with SAP Build Process Automation

Also, feel free to ask if you want me to cover other topics or if you would like to know more about SAP Document AI Premium combined with SAP Build Process Automation.
